GAME: San Juan
RANK: 224
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fast and fun, the lighter version of Puerto Rico, also for non-gamers. It makes use of the well-know mechanics of the original boardgame, but adds less strategy and a bit more luck instead. Quick setup, so it's perfect as a filler. Great replayable value. The only thing I dislike: low interaction between players, expecially with 2 people it seems "only a run to build, the faster you can". However, awesome!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good game but became repetitive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
San Juan takes what I appreciate of Puerto Rico and boils it down to a more streamlined and enjoyable form, playable in half the time. Simple and fast, it rewards strategy and tactics without becoming too much chess-like. Simpler and with less variety than Race for the Galaxy, it is also more elegant and accessible. Luck is present, but not to the point of making a mess of your strategy: even if not all the buildings seem to be balanced, it's really hard to be left without viable options. Interaction between players is still limited: you have to choose the role that maximizes your advantage and minimizes your rivals' gains, and keep a look at what paths they're following, but that's it. Really good with 3 players, still good with 2, less enjoyable with 4.

RGG version. Simple components, good quality. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A few years back this saw quite a lot of play, but it has started feeling samey. Definitely overshadowed by the more complex Race for the Galaxy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Card version of Puerto Rico.  But much easier to play.  Each turn is not so critical and it is not so obvious if you have made a mistake.  Difficult to tell who is winning until the end.
Quick to play and quick to learn.
The more I play this the more I like it.

RATING: 9
before Glory to Rome and Dominion this was my favourite 2 player card game. There are several strategies to win and you need to adopt one that suits the cards you draw. Some detractors say it is very luck based but this is like saying the same about Bridge

RATING: 6
I loved how the cards could be used for multiple things (currency, buildings, production), and I adore variable phase selection (ala Puerto Rico, Glory to Rome). The theme isn't bad. The downside here mostly comes in the form of the end game; there are so few ways of ending the game, that you're options for winning strategies are somewhat narrow. Hands down best at 4p. I find I want to play about twice a year, otherwise I'd pick up it's cousin Glory to Rome instead.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Essentially the card version of Puerto Rico, that stands alone as a very solid game in it's own right.

The excellent role selection mechanic of Puerto Rico is used here, with the innovative idea of the cards having several uses (money, goods, buildings).

This game is simple to pick up and play, and it works very well with 2-players.  However, if you have more than 2 players, I'd recommend playing Puerto Rico, unless space and/or time is an issue, as this game is very portable and reasonably quick.  It should also be noted that this is more of a "racing" game with 2-players, as the game ends once someone builds 12 buildings.

This is a strategy game, despite the fact that luck of the draw can be a significant factor, and some of the buildings can be very unbalanced at times (ex: Library, Guild Hall).

I'm not a huge fan of this game, but I respect it's solid design, and it gets played a TON around here, as my wife absolutely loves it.  Considering the quality and low cost of the game, I'd recommend this game even if you already have Puerto Rico.

Own the [boardgame=165355]New Buildings & Events[/boardgame] expansion cards from the [boardgame=40688]Treasure Chest[/boardgame].

RATING: 8
I really like San Juan. It's a short, fun, strategic card game that is easy to play and teach. The ease of play and focus on the roles are two things the game really has going for it. And I hate Puerto Rico and don't care for Race for the Galaxy.

I'm thinking about re-theming this game to be "Twilight Imperium: the card game", because the theme is pretty much the only thing I would change about this game, if I could. :p

I mean that there is a pretty large luck component in the cards you are able to draw and build. But there's probably strategies to overcome this that I just haven't figured out yet, like using the councilor effectively.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I've played Puerto Rico for years and rate it highly. I've played Race for the Galaxy and didn't enjoy it - and still don't after many (apparently required to grok it) plays. So what could fit in the middle? San Juan! Bought it at my FLGS and got in a play with my wife - my favorite 2-player gamer! We had a good time with it, but like Trajan, I wasn't blown away. It feels a bit ho-hum somehow. I think it is better for me and mine than Race without doubt because it runs smoother and faster and (yes) easier. So I give it decent marks and will very likely get it to the table many times in the future.

EDIT: More plays (just 2-player) means I like it more. There is a bit of luck with it, but I *think* skill still wins the day. There are some pretty interesting cards to play and I'd like to try it more just to see this aspect.

EDIT: More plays and I am very much in love with it as a nice weight, 2, 3 or 4 player game. I think of it as a slightly heavier filler game. So good in that space - and really unique in my collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Very clever card version of Puerto Rico. I love that it's simpler to setup and play, and admire how much of the lavour of the original they managed to keep. However, I miss the passive aggressive player interaction of the original (San Juan has very little interaction) and the loss of shipping limits the paths to victory somewhat.

A good game in it's own right. 

Update 2008 06 23:

This game is superseded by the similar, but in my opinion superior, Race for the galaxy and Glory to Rome. The only advantage of San Juan is simplicity... unfortunately it's not what I'm after.

RATING: 8
Very much a Eurogame -- play your cards: your decisions help you in one way and hurt you in another.  Due to the nature of the cards, no 2 games are the same.  Very enjoyable and versatile: 2 player games and 4 player games are equally enjoyable.  This is my wife's favorite 2-player Euro.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Puerto Rico's baby brother comes good. The cards dictate your options, but within these there are many choices to make. The roles remain at the heart of the game and the new role is enjoyable and appropriate for the new game. The cards have multiple uses, and this adds to the confusion and difficulty but after a few games they quickly become clear. The speed of the game is really good - hardly any downtime as the multiple options are considered and the use of cards means that the atmosphere is much more relaxed than PR. This will attract more people to play San Juan, while a few who relish the control within PR may be put off. 
Overall rating after 5 games is excellent.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An excellent game.  Role selection, hand management, variable trade values.

The Race for the Galaxy precursor.  I came at this one backwards, having played many games of Race before I reached San Juan.  The commonalities are numerous and obvious.  I've been told before that once you've played Race there really isn't a reason to go (back) to San Juan.  That's spot on.  It's unfortunate because this really is a good game, it's just obsolete.  If you like Race, you should play San Juan once (but no more, really) just to see what a pre-Race world was like.

My rating reflects my willingness to play it more than the game itself.  Had I played San Juan pre-Race, I probably would have rated it an 8 or 9.  Now, however, I have it at a 7 due to it being outmoded.

RATING: 2
Wow, so boring. 

I can't believe people prefer this to Race, or anything really. 

The cards are all so linear, yet even then there is a clear hierarchy. 

...and five role selections where two are dependent on each other and the last is a copout? What the hell. 

I think this might be the most overrated game of all time.

RATING: 8
STRATEGY 

This is a card game in which you construct buildings and produce goods, such as coffee and sugar, in the city of San Juan, Puerto Rico. Player with the most victory points wins! Maggie and I really like this one. A good lunch time selection.

We own the expansions for the game that are included in the Treasure Chest. They are in the box.

Recommended with 2-4 players (best 3). 45-60 mins.

RATING: 6
I like SJ because the mechanics are fairly simple and the game plays quickly, yet it's still an involved game. 

My only issue with SJ is that some games can get repetitive with 2 players. If you get the right cards, you can overwhelm your opponent quite easily. I've had several games with my bf where one of us gets all the cards that let you produce an extra good and sell an extra good, and that player simple churns out buildings and collects off the "6" buildings at the end of the game. In one game, I didn't get any of those producer/trader bonus cards and had to frantically (yet slowly due to a smaller production capacity) build monuments, other high point cards (I ended up with 2 silver smelters), and store chapel cards just to be somewhat competitive. 

Ah yeah, I also love the score sheets. In fact, every game should come with one - recording dates, players, and game wins is easier than ever!

Tracked on family game list (grooven).

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
These days Race for the Galaxy casts a long shadow over San Juan.  Race has more cards (buy all the expansions and have many more), more viable strategies and, to me, a more appealing theme.

San Juan's advantages are all in terms of simplicity.  There are fewer rules to digest and there is card text instead of icons. New players have no need of a reference card.  Simpler doesn't mean that San Juan is stripped of interesting decisions either; building an efficient combination to produce both income and v.p.s is quite challenging.

Production quality is good, artwork is quite pleasing and the rules are clear.

RATING: 7
Loved this game, played it a lot in summer 2007. Now, I only get it out when someone else asks for it. Much prefer Race for the Galaxy in every way. Basically, seems to me that San Juan (at least with the strategies we play) relies to much on drawing the relatively small number of 6ers. In comparison Race has more 6ers, more chances to draw them, and more variety with more different strategies. 

Expansion adds a lot of new strategies, works very well.

Works well right across 2-4 players.

Unfortunately several essential 6-er cards have gone missing from my copy, hence currently listing it as Previously Owned. Also the cathedral and some events. :(

Drug this out recently for some pub play.  It's been on the shelf for almost 2 years.  What a great game in a smaller box.  We played 2 players as well as 3 players and it all ended with the "let's try that again" mentality with each one of us looking to take what we learned in that game and apply it in the next.  Multiple paths to victory, too, which is nice.  In one game, the Chapel was the path to the win.  In another game, dual City Halls was too much to overcome.  Of all the more cult of the new games that I've been playing, it's refreshing to remind myself that some of the titles in my collection for years are still solid plays.

RATING: 9
San Juan is the faster, simpler version of Puerto Rico. The game is quite fun, essentially a city building card game. Yet, there is a lot of cost-benefit decision making. Do you build up buildings or do build up your farms to get more resources? Do you build up now and end the game, or wait till the time is right? I highly recommend this game, especially for fans of Puerto Rico who would like to play something faster.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Comes with the expansion cards from the Treasure Chest.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Having gone back and played a reasonable amount of San Juan, I have to say, it plays differently than Race for the Galaxy in some subtle ways. For one, it's an awful lot simpler in that there are many fewer unique cards, meaning there are also fewer mechanics. It's not only easier to teach than RftG, but it also allows for somewhat more reliable strategies. Good combinations are more important to remember because they're more likely to happen. There's still the issue of 6-cost buildings, but it's somewhat mitigated by the fact that, as with most (if not all) other buildings, there's more than one copy of each available.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
"Puerto Rico Light".  As a teaching game for Puerto Rico, the game works well.  As a light fast version of Puerto Rico, the game works well.  As a game, it suffers the same problems as its big brother.  Play can feel like it is not in the player's control and thus leaves players feeling played by the game.  Because of the card draw aspect, the game feels more random and less strategic than Puerto Rico.  [GTI Code: TGCL]

RATING: 8
Plays well with 2 and I enjoy playing solitaire also.  The learning curve on this is not nearly as steep as Puerto Rico, and plays more quickly.  Experienced Puerto Rico players may complain that it's too luck driven.  This is a friendlier game for non-gamers than Puerto Rico and isn't nearly so brutal on beginners.  The mistake that I see most often with people learning to play is that the victory points are at the bottom of the card, not the number at the top.  I often put too much emphasis on production and trading when I could be more effective.

RATING: 6
See Puerto Rico.  Simpler and all card based.  Less turn order dependent, but more late game random.  But that I mean that the last turn or two can easily dictate a third or more of your victory points. So in that short window the luck-of-the-draw element is pretty strong.  Not really a problem though, because as a card game you pretty much accept luck-of-the-draw as part of the landscape.

Still, versus something like Hearts this game pales.

update:  low interaction really starts to undermine this.  Race for the Galaxy opened my eyes to this (by having the same problem).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This is the card game version of Puerto Rico. Overall, it is a fairly good adaptation as it maintains the interesting role-selection mechanic in Puerto Rico. In this mechanic, a player selects an action, which all other players take. The key is to select actions that will benefit yourself more than other players. For instance, producing goods when no other player has the ability/space to produce good. 

That being said, the card game is considerably lighter than Puerto Rico. And drawing specific cards, at certain points of the game, can effect the outcome. I don't want to suggest that this is some luck-fest (it is not)... it's just that the decisions are much more superficial than Puerto Rico. And considering the time it takes to play this game (45+ mins), I find myself wanting to play Puerto Rico instead. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I've play San Juan on my phone around 80 times before playing in person, but it still manged to surprise and delight me. First, I really like the components, the cards are nice, the role and shipping placards are thick and sturdy and the included pencil and scorepad are a nice touch. It has a nice balance between easy of place and strategy compared to Race for the Galaxy, even if Race is the better game IMHO. San Juan is a nice appetizer/desert, while a game or two of Race is a full meal in my opinion. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.8
This is a great game to introduce to non-gamers.  Especially since it's highly portable.  

Trips to the lake, visiting family, meeting distant friends, they are all great places to bring San Juan. 

Don't let early calls of "this seems too complicated" discourage you.  After a few rounds you'll have everyone asking for one more game.  I've even encountered people in my travels who demand I leave my copy with them before I left.
:)

** update **

after many many plays the game is starting to wear a lil thin for me.  Stil very solid, especially for new players.

RATING: 8
An excellent game that forces you to play the cards you are dealt as well as possible. There are several ways to win, but if you can get Quarry, Prefecture and Carpenter early, you will have a very good chance of winning. Focus on building purple cards and hope to hit a 6 value or two as the game winds down. If you can also get the Library it will help, but it's not critical.

Take a look at my two player aids in the SJ FILES.

RATING: N/A
Box has a small dent on the top edge, almost like it had been pushed up against something round (golfball?) and slight shelf wear on the corners. Otherwise, box is solid with no split corners. Contents are complete. All cards and role placards are in super shape, and score pad still has 46 sheets on it, with scoring for four games on each one. (That's over 180 games to play!) One trading house tile has a crease and the rule set is wrinkled, but it's a great copy for those that want this presently hard to acquire game in their collection.

RATING: 10
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 2nd Place 2004[/SIZE][/COLOR]
Alea Small-Box #5

[i]Posted: 8/15/05, Rated: 9[/i]
{2P:8, 3P:9, 4P:???}

A streamlined, simplified version of [i][GAMEID=3076],[/i] played only with cards and a few tiles.  Fast, addictive play good for two or three players (I haven't tried four yet). Lack of complexity relative to bookcase games like its larger sibling should make [i]San Juan[/i] a good introduction game for new players.

Please see my [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/77965]review[/url] for more details!

Opening statistics shamelessly ripped from Fawkes.

[i]Updated: 3/26/06, Rated: 10[/i]
{2P:10, 3P:10, 4P:9}

After several playings, from two players to four, I absolutely love this game.  It is light enough to teach to new players, yet deep enough to have effective variations on strategy.  True, the cards do add quite a bit of luck to the game, but that can be mitigated somewhat with the right buildings and proper role selection.  The four player game doesn't have as much anxiety over role selection each round, since only one role will not be picked.

RATING: 7
Interesting concept and easy fun. It is not very time consuming and very easy to learn. Best played with some time between games to make it stay fun. Last played with 3 of my friends and with a secret expansion.

The goal is to build up the city of San Juan and become the permanent govenor. When the first player reaches 12 properties the game is over but it is not necessarily he/she who wins. Properties are worth different points and when counted together the winner is determined.

Expansion tries to add even more depth and choises to the game

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
San Juan is a nice, fast game which still has a significant amount of strategy to it.

Overall I'd say it's a bit unbalanced.  A high-production strategy is usually the best and whoever can execute on it first is tough to beat.  The other roles are have their own strategies, but none of them are as effective as straight up production because production gives you both the options of what to play as well as the means to play it.  There is very little player interaction, so it's mostly a matter of making the most of the cards you receive.

Still, San Juan is great fun and withstands hundreds of plays.  Great for two or three or even four.  One suggestion I make is to replace using cards as production barrels by using tokens instead, which cuts down greatly on reshuffling without changing the character nor tactics of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great 2-player alternative for Puerto Rico. Plays quick and it's pretty easy to teach. Ultimately, I'm hoping this will act as a first-step in convincing my wife to play Race for the Galaxy. They seem pretty similar and she doesn't seem to mind just about any theme she's presented with so I think we'll be able to make the switch pretty soon.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[url=http://ballearicus.blogspot.com/2011/12/san-juan.html]San Juan[/url] tiene dificultad media, no es complicado, pero no trivial.  De reglas fáciles pero no simples, las estrategias son claras pero no evidentes. El análisis-parálisis no es desesperante al no tener muchas decisiones complejas que tomar. No apto para todos los público, para jugones es ligero. Juego perfecto para dar el salto cualitativo y pasar de un nivel de complejidad familiar a jugón de más injundia y mantenerlos dentro. Como juego para matar el rato o por su magnifica potabilidad, tiene su nicho. 

La selección de roles y la variedad de edificios, y un mecanismo que funciona muy bien, crean un dinamismo que hace que funcione sin problemas y presenta un constante desafío. 

Me gusta, es un juego sólido, aunque no es un gran juego. Sólo un buen juego de cartas, que no es poco.

RATING: 9
Brilliant little simplification of Puerto Rico; plays well with 2.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
When I want to describe this game, there's one key word that comes to mind...elegant.  This game just seems to flow so nicely.  I love the interaction of the different buildings, and the various ways you can score points.  Perhaps the coolest thing is the way that you find yourself desperate to take all the different roles on your turn but you can only take one.  So what do you do?  It also works great as a 2-player game, which is a nice added feature.

I think this game is light years ahead of Race for the Galaxy.  The fact that the mechanisms are more straightforward and the actions are spelled out with words instead of silly symbols on the cards make this game a winner for my family and other new players.  I'm also amazed how much interaction is added to the proceedings by only allowing one player to use each role.  It completely takes away the multi-player solitaire issue that many complain about in RftG, because you always have to watch what your opponents are doing.  This game is definitely one I want to add to my collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Miguel

RATING: 9

Unfortunately, the game comes down to luck, when playing with someone else, who has played San Juan often and knows well, what works and what doesn't. Also, when playing the game with people, who never played before, its almost impossible not to win.

RATING: 7
Decent tableau-building game that really does play like Puerto Rico-lite.

Not as much variation in strategies as I would like, and there are too many buildings that are too expensive for their effect (e.g. the production-related violet buildings) compared to the other buildings available.  But it's fast to play and easier to explain than Race for the Galaxy.

I'm looking forward to seeing how the expansion changes things.

RATING: 9
Initial impressions after about 20 games were unfavorable.  I think it was because I played on BSW and got stomped without any real reason as to why.  FtF play unveiled the game to me, but I was spoiled by the quick plays of BSW.  

A great card game that has surpassed Puerto Rico in my view.  The delicious hand management restricts choices and provides a variability sorely lacking in its older sibling—all while adding another layer of strategic depth.  By distilling the best of Puerto Rico and attaching some luck, Seyfarth crafted his masterpiece.

Basically, it comes down to the question of why play San Juan when I could play RftG.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
Cheap to purchase.  Worth every penny.  Easy to learn and let a person build tactics/strategies for other harder games.
  This game follows the pattern of selecting a role or worker and with that selection you gain an advantage allong the same lines but everyone playing also gets the primary action you choose, less the advantage.  It all is based on cards that are traded as currency and also come up as various buildings to build and what not, found also in Peurto Rico.  I would consider this game to be RFtG light or Peurto Rico light.

This game is a great way to pass an hour or two.

These days, most gamers seem to prefer the "meatier" Race for the Galaxy, but I prefer San Juan's faster and more streamlined play. Many interesting decisions despite a limited amount of cards. Luck can certainly be a factor, but it's a fast game, so it's not such a big deal.

RATING: 6
This was my gateway Euro and still one of my favorites.  Personally, I prefer this to Puerto Rico because (1) the cards keep the game from becoming to dry and analytical and (2) the idea of using cards for money, seeds, and building/plantations makes for some tough decisions and is just plain different.

For more details, see my review.

RATING: 8.5
Cambiado a Wend1g0 de la bsk en sep10 por el Caylus Magna Carta. 
Adaptación estupenda del juego Puerto Rico para disfrutar igual con sólo 110 cartas. Las cartas lo son todo: edificios para construir, mercancías para vender y dinero para pagar. El espíritu del juego ha quedado intacto, pero el sistema (y el tiempo de juego) ha disminuido notablemente. Es una gran adquisición.
Gana el que más puntos acumule al final de la partida, que sucede en cuanto alguien construye su decimosegundo edificio.

Vendido por 12€  en un pack a christianlafferla de la BSK, en Mayo 2014

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
(original assessment / '5')
At one time a decent card game which simulated a quick play of Puerto Rico.

Now it plays second fiddle to 'Race for the Galaxy' in my gaming circles.

(Jan 2012 update / upgrade to '7')
With the discovery of Condado, an android clone of this game, I find myself playing it much more on my tablet in order to quickly pass the time.  Condado has all the expansions, which in turn made me seek them out for my physical copy, and this will be entering the rotation again.

Where RftG got more and more complex with the various expansions, San Juan still feels fairly crisp and clean.  Getting to play it rapid fire against AI opponents on the android tablet has let me explore (without much time investment) various strategies and capabilities.

Basic strategy remains to build a card generation engine and then build, build, build, though there are other paths to victory if you can get out of the mindset that there is only one way to win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

between this and RftG, I prefer this for better accessibility and more player interaction. and this needs virtually no setup time unlike Puerto Rico.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The role choosing mechanism provides the similar flavor to the great Puerto Rico, making it a favorite, though the roles are slightly different. Nice scale of the game to get the twelve buildings, so the game is not too long, yet presents enough time to make a plan. The game really plays well with 3 players, also works with 2 or 4 players. UPDATE: It can occasionally happen that a player does not draw the big (6 cost) bonus cards for end-game scoring. However, playing the card earlier, instead of discarding, may need to be contemplated to avoid this end game issue. UPDATE: The expansion seems to address this with the new Cathedral building, after sevveral plays. Overall, the new cards are a positive addition with extra choices and variety. The new event cards add just enough to the game, and I would not want anything more added as it has reached the limit of decisions that should be available.

RATING: 6.5
As a big fan of RFTG and 51st state, I assumed I would like this game. Admittedly, I was sure it would be light in comparison to those other games. After my first play (a close 32 to 31 point loss), I was not all that enamoured. There just aren't that many different routes to victory and the choices don't seem so interesting. For folks that are intimidated by the iconography of RFTG or 51st state, I can understand preferring this game. For me, I would much rather play the heftier card games. I think San Juan will go to the summer home.

RATING: 8
After about 50 ftf plays and probably 200 on iOS, I feel like I've played San Juan out. Most decisions are made on auto-pilot now and I don't feel like I'm learning anything more about the game. It was really fun getting to this point, but I've sold it on and will concentrate on RftG for my tableau-building card gaming pleasure :)

After the first play with the expansion buildings (haven't used the events yet), they're neat but seem somewhat overpowered - specifically the Bank and the Gold Office or whatever it's called - one player got 8 or 10 cards out of it throughout the game, which seems like a LOT.

Many, many plays later (at least 40 not recorded here on BGG) and I still really like SJ.  I like its streamlined game play and the ability to set up neat combos.  I really wish I could play this more.

I do think it's best with 4, so the production strategy has a chance. With only 2 or 3 players, it's too hard to produce by yourself, leading to one-dimensional play.

RATING: 6

UPDATE: After playing it again circa 2014 I really don't find much to recommend in San Juan, especially after playing Race for the Galaxy. There are really only a couple of viable strategies at most. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the most elegant card games ever made. The cards-as-currency system is pure genius. Has a lot of the fun of Puerto Rico but in a simpler, quicker form. That said, even with the added inherent luck of the draw it does start to feel scripted after a lot of play. However, that doesn't really stop the game from being great and it truly is impressive that they managed to balance it so that there are multiple equally valid paths to victory. So even though I do tire of it from time to time, San Juan remains a fantastic game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
As a card version of Puerto Rico, San Juan is pretty good. My favorite card game type of the shared role selection is still Glory to Rome. But, San Juan is the better choice if you want to play with folks or family that are not up for the rigors of a more difficult game.

San Juan is pretty simple, with two things that elevates the difficulty for non-gamers: cards act as buildings, money, and goods... and a new player has to struggle through all the different types of purple buildings. But once they learn those concepts, they can actually start playing the game for fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fun, and it can move more quickly than its partner game PR.  It's a great shorter length game to break out between games, especially when there's not much table space.  One problem I've heard people complain about with this game is that some of the 6-point buildings are overpowered; whether those really act as "trump" cards depends on the rest of one's buildings though, in my opinion.  There is some luck involved with pulling the right cards to go with one's strategy though--especially if other players are burying those same cards in their chapel graveyards.  I like PR better than San Juan, but San Juan is less analysis paralysis-prone.

RATING: 10
We generally play this 2-player, and have never played Puerto Rico.   We were worried about the length of the rulebook, but had no trouble playing.  This is a very interesting game, which we both enjoy regardless of who wins.  The basic idea is similar to that of Citadels.  Although Citadels is a little simpler, San Juan has no confrontation.  It feels like you are playing to see how well you can do with the cards you get, more than competing with others.  We have played a couple times with 3 or 4 players, and it seems to accomodate any number nicely.

Another update: I was just looking at my ratings and, you know, there is just no other game that I am always psyched to play. How could it not be a 10?

Update: Having played Race for the Galaxy a number of times, I just played SJ for the first time in a while. SJ just strikes me as such a much better game. The role selection mechanism and the fewer cards just make the game much more interactive for me. In RftG, I just feel like I'm trying to do my own thing and occasionally latch on to someone else's role selection like a parasite.

Originally rated an 8, but my wife and i keep coming back to it over and over. It just scratches that short-game-with-some-thinking-but-not-too-much itch.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
UPDATE 11/16: After more San Juan and more Race For the Galaxy in my life, I have come around to the opinion that there is no coherent argument for San Juan in a world where Race exists, with the minute exception of the fact that San Juan has an iOS adaptation and Race, thanks in no small part to the malignant influence of the trickster god that has sullied my memory of the year the Cubs finally won the world series with things like "President-Elect Trump" and "All The Cool Musicians Are Now Dead," does not. So.

---

A quick-playing tableau-builder that builds off of the mechanics of big brother Puerto Rico. More accessible and approachable than Race For The Galaxy (the other PR card game, for all intents and purposes), and unlike RFTG, role-selection and turn order matters a great deal, so it's a little truer to the original board game in ways besides theme. SJ is a bit more self-contained than RFTG, as well, which is both good and bad -- good because it's a complete game out of the box whereas Race was designed from the ground up with expansions in mind, but bad because you will likely hit a point where you go "that's it?" (Also, gamers being gamers, there's more of an audience for aliens and pew-pew laser guns than coffee roasting, so San Juan is a tough sell to RFTG fans, grumble grumble grumble.)

San Juan is a good warmup/nightcap game, easily portable, and fun. But it's not a game that grabs you by the lapels and demands your attention.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
San Juan takes my feelings about PR feeling like Magic in board game form, and adds to them by taking it into the realm of card play. More than just a blatant cash in on the PR name, but definitely lighter than its sibling, whether that is good or not is obviously subjective. It seems as though your strategy is going to be, by and large, dictated by the cards you draw in the early going though, and it's much more of a solitaire game than PR as it tends to reward specialisation in one or two phases more than PR and doesn't penalise you as much for not taking certain roles because there is no bonus associated with choosing unselected options. Much better 2 man than the PR variant rules though IMO, and the faster setup and playtime make this an ideal way to fill some time while still thinking as compared to the weight of many filler games, which are generally on the light end of the spectrum. (note: I also strongly feel that this game is quite superior to St. Pete because of the creativity inherent in finding optimum building combinations...I honestly don't understand why the two games *are* compared to begin with as aside from their release dates and claim to being board games played with cards they really have few similarities, but I guess that doesn't really matter.)

SJ is largely obsolete in the post-Race world though. I still much prefer SJ's action selection mechanism, which is a straight pull from PR, but this game feels very limited by comparison.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Must be treated as a seperate game to Peurto Rico despite the family resembalance.  It does not need to engage the brain on the same level since the cards and the situation often narrow your decisions right down.  Also the luck element is important and playing your hand to best of your ability may be your only satisfaction sometimes.

Still very enjoyable and after a bad run you can always blame the hand you were dealt even if you missed your opportunities and let the others off the hook.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

RATING: 8
OK, after 15 plays I have to rewrite my review.  This game is fantastic. It retains not only the role selection mechanic of PR but also the high-wire tension in selecting and optimizing every turn.  The cardplay system is brilliant, inspired, and sure to be cloned ad nauseum.  Cards are your buildings and your currency, so you never have a worthless card and the economic structure is solely based on getting more cards.  I'm sort of flabbergasted, really...MUCH better than I had anticipated, particularly since I don't care for card games.  2 player games can speed by in 25 minutes but with a great deal of depth.  I still would rather see Seyfarth do something totally new though, but this will do nicely for now.

RATING: 8

Sold my copy, but only because it fetched $40 due to OOP price increase.  Love this game and will purchase when the reprint eventually comes, which will probably contain the expansion cards.  LOL

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I find it interesting to reflect on the relationship between San Juan and Puerto Rico; and Caylus Magna Carta and Caylus. Heck, I could even throw in the E&T duo for good measure. Learning San Juan is quite simple and straightforward, and features a nice hand management mechanic in how cards are used for buildings, points, goods and other stuff. Once you're into the game you can simply focus on getting your economic engine going, and hoping that you draw good cards at the right time. The result is quite a streamlined version of Puerto Rico which won't take as long to play. In this respect the card game once again wins from the boardgame in terms of ease of play.

What I'm not so enthusiastic about is that there doesn't seem to be an awful lot of choice nor player interaction. In the four-player game the role selection mechanic becomes rather boring after a while and not at all as agonising as it is with its bigger brother. There is hardly ever a choice you can fret over, so basically you pick what suits you best and hope that you profit more from that role than do your opponents. The fun then comes in from attempting to construct various 'good combos' which have your ecomomy running at peak efficiency, and seeing how your theories compare against those of others. This game, like so many other economy games, is therefore not fun to play if your opponents differ too much in level of skill.

It is a friendly conversion of the boardgame, but compared against its cousins, I still say CMC is better. There the luck of the draw was relegated very wisely to a personal deck, so there is no question of someone getting an inherently better card than someone else. CMC changes nature as easily as a leopard its spots because of the random starter buildings. CMC can put the squeeze on all players because of a much more lively economy—it is to some extent shared, so you 'feel' what others are doing far more directly. It would have been fairly easy to give San Juan a similar constrained feel, and I find it somewhat disappointing to discover that it didn't. It is not fair to make one game an arbitrary yard stick and expect another game to hold up: San Juan is of course its own game. But I cannot help but thinking that a bit more bite wouldn't have hurt at all.

[b]Update[/b] It has been eons since I wrote the above, and when I finally got around to playing San Juan anew, I find my thoughts on the game echoing the above to the letter. If anything the lack of variety bites even more anno 2016. Which probably explains why games like Race for the Galaxy took off so strongly: there's simply more to do there. San Juan is simple and straightforward, which is good... but it's also its Achilles' heel, because that is [i]all[/i] it is. Still, nice to have played again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

[/c]

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very good medium-weight engine building/racing card game for small groups of players. Mechanically quite simple, but there are many strategic options available to players. It's all about building an engine of card combos, and will appeal to players who like that. The interaction between players is basically limited to the role selection, so it has a multiplayer solitaire feel to it (Puerto Rico is much more interactive). Inexperienced players are at very steep disadvantage until they learn all the cards and understand the combos possible, which can take many plays. The "churn rate" of cards is quite high - you'll usually shuffle the deck at least once during the course of a game - so there is a good chance that any particular card will at some point be in your hand.

The first edition suffers from some balance issues. The Guild Hall strategy is easy to execute and difficult for new players to counter, especially without the expansion cards that are included in the second edition. I don't care for the event cards from the expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Pretty much a lighter version of Puerto Rico. It´s faster than the basic game but that´s all the merit it have on that game. Could be good for introduction for later Puerto Rico gaming. 

Update 091204: I have now sold this game, not because I dislike it in anyway but because I didn´t play so often anymore and better to make room for some other game. At least I hope I will play it sometime in the future again!

RATING: 6
great little card game. perfect for traveling
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Components: Very close to being just a straight-up card game. The score pad is nice, but a bit unnecessary; I would have preferred if the game came in an Amigo-sized card box. For the amount of action the cards see, they should be linen-finished. The artwork is nice. 

Experience: My opinion of this game has much improved since I first played it in 2004. Then I found it somewhat similar to Citadels, and was not yet inclined to enjoy production engine games. Now, of course, I find it more similar to Race for the Galaxy. San Juan might serve as a good gateway to RftG, with its simplified rule-breaking violet cards. Produce/trade restrictions and the hand limit keep cards very tight; it's crucial to find the right balance of violet cards to better piggy-back off the role selection. I'm not going to like this as much as RftG, but now I have a better sense of what people see in it.

Eagerness to Play Again: Soon

Plays (3):
2 players: 1
4 players: 2

RATING: 6
Dislike 2 player: Production is useless.
Dislike 3 player: Production is only OK if one other is doing it. If you are the one producer and neither of the other players is, you are going to lose.
Like 4 player: Someone will have to take production roles every round, but ultimately, the buildings aren't that exciting.

After playing Glory to Rome, this feels really shallow. A shadow of Puerto Rico and not nearly as good at GtR. I've also played Race for the Galaxy which has a more interesting theme, more wildly deviating player abilities and is just a better game all around.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
It's a good game, but I think it's overrated.  I believe that it would have an average rating on the Geek right around 6 if it wasn't related to Puerto Rico.  Just because "everyone" likes Puerto Rico doesn't automatically make this a great game.

I am not sure I like the angst of role selection in this style of game any longer.  It's hard to feel confident in any choice you make when you know you are helping your opponents out as well.  

This bugs me some about Puerto Rico, but San Juan compounds this feeling for me.  In San Juan, there are so many ways to offset the privilege of a particular role by building the right building, that you soon feel like there are no choices that help only you.  

As the game proceeds, any advantage you get for picking a particular role is very likely negated by someone else's building or buildings.  

The complexity of the interaction between the different buildings made me feel like the game was more analytical than I wanted it to be.  I prefer Citadels, where the analysis is less of a cold calculation.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Mostly harmless. Less confrontational, less brainpower and much more luck than Puerto Rico. I expect this game will be decent filler, but mostly forgotten and unplayed in a few years... 6 months later I am proven wrong. It is one of my most popular 2 player fillers with the following changes: removal of library, prefecture costs one more, and guildhall only scores for each type of production building. Upgraded it's rating by .5.

Update though I played this a lot RFTG wins out over this one for me, hands down. My wife prefers the non science fiction theme San Juan.

RATING: 9
Excellent game of hand management. Works well with 2-4 although you may want to make a couple of small changes for two players. No real player interaction although role selection (a la Puerto Rico) does allow you to pick something else another player may need. Using cards in your hand as money to pay for buildings is brilliant and really makes hand management challenging.

One of my favorite games. There are several different valid strategies and adapting as the game goes on is key.

Not as fun as Race for the Galaxy, but much easier to learn (and teach).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
(2011?)
Per 2-4 jugadors.
Es juga íntegrament amb cartes.
Partides relativament ràpides (< 60 min) i que poden ser encarades amb diferents estratègies.
La idea és construir el teu poble o ciutat, combinant Plantes de producció de recursos (cada recurs es vendrà més barat o més car en funció de l'estat del mercat) i Edificis que aportaran millores (permetran produir més, abaratir costos de construcció, etc).
Totes les cartes són d'edificis (urbans o centres de producció) però a la vegada s'usen com a 'monedes' de canvi, per pagar allò que vols construir.
A cada ronda, es passa el càrrec de governador al jugador següent i aquest escollirà un rol d'entre 5 disponibles (cada rol et permet fer unes o altres coses). Els demés jugadors escolliran els altres rols disponibles. Quan s'ha fet una ronda completa, el càrrec de Governador passa al següent jugador, i aquest escollirà el rol que desitgi (passant les cartes de rol restants als demés jugadors).
Molt recomanable.

RATING: 9
Outstanding, simplified, card-based rework of [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/game/3076]Puerto Rico[/url]. Cards can be used to build buildings that produce resources, build buildings that provide other benefits, or can be used to purchase the buildings themselves. A very clean design that is easy to teach and to play. Everyone should try this game.

I like the addition of a little card luck to the PR theme. Players are more likely to play fast & loose instead of analysing it to death. Its also easier to introduce to beginners since its simpler, more streamlined and looks less daunting than the myriad of PR components ("Hey its only a deck of cards!"). Like all card games, you need to play the hand you're dealt rather than any pre-planned strategy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[2008-07-10]
Bought my copy of San Juan at Amazon for ~14€. Will update my comment and add a rating once i've got some games under my belt.

[2008-08-12]
While my gaming group seems to have vanished and I'm eagerly looking for a new one, I'm killing some time with a San-Juan-Java-Implemention called JSanJuan. After about 20 to 30 games I have to say that I really like this game and so I updated my rating. It plays faster than Puerto Rico, there are other strategies and there is a nice, little addition of luck through the card draw. One thing I'm not so sure about is the replayability. There seem to be about two or three major strategies. Which one to choose and how well they execute depends on your card-draws. I'm not quite sure yet, if the game might get a bit repetitive after a while. Maybe Race for the Galaxy (RftG) might be the better choice when it comes down to replayability since both games share the core gameplay and from what I read here on the geek, there are far more possible strategies in RftG. But also after reading a ton of positive reviews for RftG, I can't convince myself to buy it because of the icons. So i think, I'll stick happily with San Juan for a while and update my rating again, once I've played the game face to face.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Rating based on 1580 plays (give or take a dozen).  Do I need to say more?  Well, OK, I will.  The game is all about making the most of what you are dealt.  It is much more balanced when you understand the interactions among the different cards.  Different game with 2 than 3 or 4.  When I play and someone suggests a variation such as no library, I laugh because I likely won't build it anyway (unless I'm swimming in otherwise sucky cards early in the game).  There is no single card that is all powerful (IMO Prefecture approaches this in a 4 player game).  Gold mine adds a little more luck to it, but the luck is manageable most of the time.  My favorite 2 player game.  Get it.  Play it.  Love it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Quality Puerto Rico spin-off game.  The "choosing the role" mechanic remains, but now there are only five roles.  Cards are either money (when in hand), Buildings (when on table) or goods (when on production Building).  Lots of good stuff to think about when juggling what card to use as money/building.  Plays very cleanly and quickly.  Rating up from 8 to 9 after 20 games.

RATING: 9
I play this quite frequently with my partner, it makes a great lunch hour game.  There are not many different strategies to explore, but you don't always have a choice and need to work with what you draw.  There isn't anything especially amazing about this game, but it has interesting decisions and a nice relaxing flow to it.  I was about to bump the rating down as we had started to get bored with the limited amount of winning strategies, but we just picked up the Treasure Chest expansion, which adds additional strategies.

Update: after a bit of a break I've played this again and continue to appreciate it more, especially with the expansion.  I would rate this an 8 without the expansion and 9 with it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Hosszú idő után vettük elő, a magyarított, és kártyagyáras rethematizált SJ-t. (Rhethema: hát határeset. Nem rossz, nem rossz, de a tényleg magyar SJ jobban összerakott: témailag, na de ugye az nem rendelhető, de persze magyarul SEM kapható...). Na de ami a lényeg: A Filosofia oldalán találtam egy linket, és hivatalos szabályt is 5-8 fősségre. 2 pakli kell hozzá, meg pár új szerep. Szuper. Ezt is megcsináltattam pluszba.
És megvolt a próba: az újra előkerülés egyben 6 személyes játékot hozott. És működik!
Nyilván nőtt a játék idő: mégiscsak 6 fő a 4 helyett. De nem lett élvezhetetlen, sőt. Izgalmas maradt, hossza is megfelelő (de nem rövid!: nekünk kb 2 óra volt. előtte mivel nem volt szétválogatva rendesen a pakli, sajnos volt fél óra válogatás, átszervezés, ez orvosolva, legközelebb nincs ilyen. Ugyanakkor a 2 órához még: ismerve a társaságot a 4 fős játék is 1,5 óra lenne, így valóban nem sokkal hosszabb).
És ugye azt se felejtsük: az eredeti SJ is könnyedebb verziója a PR-nek, ez is megmaradt.
És akkor az SJ:
szerepválasztásos, eggyel több szerep mint játékos, 1 forduló: szerepválasztás, a szerep lejátszása, a választó elébb aztán mindenki más ha akarja, a választó plusz kiváltságot kap. Majd köv. játékos választ a maradékból szerepet. Miután mindenki választott szerepet a forduló véget ér, minden szerep visszakerül. És új forduló.
A kártya lehet pénz -ha fizetünk, lehet termény, ha termelünk, lehet áru eladáskor, és persze lehet épület, amit megépítünk. Ez utóbbi a fontos: ebből van pont a játék végén. Minden épületnek van pontértéke.
Amikor vki megépíti a 12. épületét, a játék véget ér, pontszámolás jön.
Az épület: a termelőépületek (csak termelnek.)
vagy b: különlege3s -lila- épületek. ez utóbbiak többnyire adnak vmi spec tulajdonságot: többet termelhetsz, többet adhatsz el, 2x jössz, több lapod lehet, stb.
összesen 24 féle lila épület: abból 17nek spec tulajdonsága. 3 emlékmű, és 4 spec pontokat ad. 
Még mindig szeretem, sőt kap magasabb pontot is: az h 6-an is játszható: megérdemli.

RATING: 5.5
Received in trade 5/26/11.

First play 6/25/11 with my husband.  I found it so-so.  I don't know if my expectations were too high, or that this title just requires more plays to enjoy it.  The reason I found it so-so, was that I found it repetitive and a bit boring.  Maybe when we know the cards better?  I'm not really happy about this right now!  :(

2nd play 7/4/11 with my husband.  It was a bit better.  My issue with this game is that, while sort of interesting, it does not challenge me and I find that I can easily win with minimal effort.  Regardless of what my husband does, I can counteract it and still outscore him.  Not exciting at all.  I rated it as I have very little desire to play again.

FOR TRADE.

Played 3-player on 12/25/12.  2 new players.  Still very meh for me and the new players were not thrilled either.  The gameplay gets pretty repetitive.

Traded for TZAAR 9/4/13.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
(iOS ver)
Yes!
After years of struggle with RftG, I can finally see the light!! After getting bloodied time and again by the Keldon AI, I can enjoy playing a card game with very similar lines, but certainly shallower, and it is perhaps more fun because of it. Is a win more satisfying in RftG? Perhaps. But there's a lot less trauma with San Juan. Honestly, they are so similar, it's kind of ridiculous, but SJ is FAR more scrutable than Race, and thematically as laid back as the Caribbean its self.  

Frankly, they're both great games, but SJ is going to be easier to get to the table, and require less gray matter at the end of a hard day. Get both!

The various new buildings, and tweaked roles keep this game both familiar and distinct. I won't play much, but I won't renounce it either.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
"75% the fun of PUERTO RICO in 50% of the time"

Card game variation of Puerto Rico, lighter in tone, easier, and quicker. It's an exercise in economic logistics, with different paths to victory (eg production strategy?  monument strategy?  other?), and the idea is to find optimum synergy between cards with unique abilities.  Requires good decision making, and very enjoyable with 2-4, especially with three (with four players it can come down to who draws the "six point" cards).
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/163555]Article[/url] about theoretical highest possible score.

Also own the expansion cards from the Alea Treasure chest: [gameid=165355]

See my pictorial review: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/786738
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

(Okay, maybe it has something to do with resourcefulness -- always balancing what you're giving up against what you're getting... it's addictive.)

I liked this one for a bit at first but playing on BSW ruined it for me as the sharks would win every time with the "build anything" strategy. Basically, you build something each turn and rush the game to a quick, 12 turn end. It removes what little strategy there is in saving up to play an endgame card that complements your strategy. I keep around as it's small enough on the shelf, but even for a gateway I prefer London at this point. And clearly Race for the Galaxy is a much more sophisticated and interesting take on the card game version of Puerto Rico. I had my fun of the game, but not sure where it fits in anymore.

update: upgraded from 7 to 8.5 after 14 plays as it just becomes better and better as you begin to understand the game flow and card combinations.

update: added the new buildings from the Treasure Chest expansion after about 40 plays.  They are great and add new life and options to this already great game.  Still going strong here and San Juan is my wife's second all-time favorite game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
There are some initial teaching hurdles in San Juan, but after learning how a face-down card constitutes a "good" that must be produced, and subsequently sold, to obtain more cards (which also function as both buildings and money!), play is quick and painless.

Everyone gets to play on everyone else's turn (provided they don't select the "Prospector" role, but even then!). This means all players are involved all the time. This engagement keeps every turn interesting and dynamic. There's a number of choices for strategy, and it is especially rewarding seeing your plays pay off on future turns.

There is little direct interaction with other players, but which role you select directly benefits them. The trick is choosing roles that help you more, and counting on others to choose the roles you didn't that you neglected but that you nonetheless need. Reading the table is key, and keeps the spirit of competition alive.

Overall a really fun game that isn't too heavy for newer gamers or too light for older gamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
* Played 5+ times. I don't think this game is very good with 2p, but it is fun with 3p, which is my least favorite number to play Puerto Rico with. Having said that, this really is a beer-and-pretzels game. Those who like the nasty indirect interaction of Puerto Rico will find little of that here. It is just denying a card to a player here or there, and therefore players seem to build buildings at roughly the same speed. This game for it's price is severely overhyped. A fairly interesting card game that uses some ideas from Puerto Rico, but is largely a solitaire exercise. [o-s]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
For many non-gamers, the cards take too long to read and become familiar with. Unfortunately, players need to know what cards are in the deck.  So now when I explain the rules, I pick out only the most important cards to briefly review.  Then we play.  I give myself a handicap by forgoing the use of the purple cards I have built. (For example, The Smithy allows the building of a production card for 1 less cost.)  I explain what I normally get for the played card.  Scores end up pretty close.  The 2nd game, I forgo use of the purple cards built on the top row only.  The third game is a full game since they are familiar enough with the cards by then.

San Juan is a lot harder to win than Puerto Rico because of the bigger luck element based on the draw of the cards--which wins/loses will be more even--the better player will win a little more often but there is less control over the game than in Puerto Rico.  but then this is a much faster game too.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Purchased in Origins 2017 Virtual Flea Market

RATING: 6.97

[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geekbuddy.php3?action=doanalyze&groupid=4204&B1=Analyze&gameid=8217]Ratings[/url]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Very simple manifestation of the Puerto Rico/Race for the Galaxy mechanic.

There is less tempo control (game only ends after building 12 cards), only one phase scores points (building, instead of Dev/Settle/Consume), it accommodates a narrower range of players, there are far fewer types of buildings, and victory depends critically on playing the large buildings. The role selection forces you to read ahead and track the way player order jumps around, which is okay in moderation but not the kind of thing I like to do.

Rftg has more "colour": many more unique cards, many more types of potentially interlocking bonuses, starting positions are asymmetric, and there are many more ways to victory.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
  San Juan keeps your hands busy as you churn through cards, shuffle, grab role tokens and discard and draw constantly.  For the most part everyone does all this together and the game keeps up a very active pace.  I like the random luck of the shuffle in San Juan and it's a game you can study and think about when not playing.  My 10 and 11 year old daughters as well as my game group enjoy this game.  It's a bonus that it's as portable and nicely produced as well!  I have many plays of this game ahead of me.  

Update:  Race for the Galaxy blows this game away.   More card combos and more depth.

RATING: 8.5
I love Puerto Rico but for some reason I was hesitant to buy this when it came out. I played it once on BSW right away and it just didn't click. After finally getting it now and playing several games, I must say that this is an excellent game. It has a lot of the flavor of Puerto Rico, but it's a completely different game. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Take the variable role selection of Puerto Rico, marry it with a card game where cards = money = special powers = victory points, and you have San Juan. It's significantly more luck-driven than its older brother, but it plays so quickly and has more than enough roads to victory that it remains interesting. Definitely in the "let's play that again" category of filler games, with more depth than you'd expect from a filler. Recommended. ***Update: Knocked SJ down another notch, to 6, as it's already wearing out its welcome after around 35+ plays. ***UPDATE: Played a few games after St. Pete crashed and burned. I like SJ more than I like St. Pete, because the card interaction and combinations are more interesting than the investment/return dynamics of St. Pete. However, neither game seems to have the staying power of a Modern Art or RA or even a LOTR: the Confrontation in 2P mode.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
O jogo é atraente pelo fato de ser baseado no Puerto Rico (PR). Mesmo tema, arte semelhante, talvez melhor, em fim, agrada aos olhos. A mecânica é escolha de ações. Construção, produção, comércio, exportação, mineração. [gameid=3076]. É um ótimo jogo para introduzir o conceito de jogos de carta (Jogos de carta baseado em jogos de tabuleiro), especialmente, por causa da comunicação visual do jogo. As cartas de ação são de cor e formatos diferentes, as cartas de edifícios de produção e violetas tem cores diferentes e o verso das cartas (recurso) é de outra cor. Facilita muita a explica e entendimento para novos jogadores. Gostei, apesar de ser um cardgame. Evidentemente, senti falta das peças de mercadorias, pontos e dinheiro, afinal é um cardgame! Também achei que o peso sorte maior que no PR, devido a retirada aleatória de cartas, mas é um jogo legal de se jogar. Se for para jogar um cardgame é esse. Recomendo.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Amazing what can be done with cards! This concentrated Puerto Rico provides extreme tension and fun from start to end. In each round the amount of required decisions is enormous! That's exactly what I love most in a game: DECISIONS!!!

RATING: 6.9
Régóta ki szerettem volna már próbálni, végre sikerült. Nem nyűgözött le, de nem is volt rossz. Kicsit kevésnek érzem a kombinációs lehetőségek számát benne, és az a baj, hogy a gyors, taktikai/stratégiai kártyajátékoknál nagyon erős a mezőny. Érzésem szerint nem ér fel sem a 7 wonders, sem a Dicsőség Rómának szintjére.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
San Juan is in many ways a massively simplified Race for the Galaxy. It has none of the sometimes overbearing iconography, but also none of the various unique card combinations.

The cards are probably the game's biggest weakness. There is little to really distinguish oneself from other players, and a few buildings are simply so much better options than others that choices border on playing on autopilot.

RATING: 4
I think Glory to Rome completely outclasses this game. So does Race for the Galaxy. Get one of those instead.

Has a nice level of complexity.  I like setting up your own sort of engine for scoring points with every game.  It is also nice in that you don't directly harm your opponents ( ie "lose a card"), you just have to plan around them.  Because of this, the game is less antagonizing.

My friend and I figured out a strategy and haven't lost using yet. So I would recommend Puerto Rico instead of this for people who like to take apart their games.

I sold this game in 2014 after purchasing it around 2005-6.

RATING: 8
Received in the mail - 4/6/04. Have now played it over 30 times. It remains one of my standard fillers. I think it is one of the few games that plays just as well with any number from 2 -4 (one set) or with 5-8 (two sets). This alone makes it a valuable game to own. Not a deep game, but a great filler, but with enough to do that you don't feel it's a "little" game. So, you won't hear me calling it a "great little filler." I call it one of the few "great meaty fillers."

RATING: 8
San Juan is a fantastic card game that captures the spirit of Puerto Rico accurately.  There are many options available throughout the game.  Having to use powerful cards as money instead makes this a real nail-biter.  There are powerful card combinations that you can look out for, but the game doesn't penalize you for experimenting with different attempts at point-gathering.  Just make sure you keep a close eye on your opponents, and can keep up with any point grabs they have set out for themselves!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
After playing RftG, San Juan just seems flat.  Removing shipping from the Puerto Rico recipe simplifies the game just a little too much.  Additionally, some cards (such as the Library) may be too powerful, while others are always used as money (ie the Crane).

On the plus side, the game is a wonderful stepping stone towards Race or Puerto Rico (and maybe Glory to Rome?), which are excellent games.

The quicker playing time makes this more available, but not as deep.

RATING: 9

I love how the cards that score victory points or get more cards into your hand are also the currency used to be able to play the cards to the table; creating some difficult choices and risk. The selecting of professions in each round also adds strategies used to limit the amount of cards your opponents can get or play. These mechanics add up to some tense rounds and a great game.

RATING: 9
San Juan is a lot of fun. It's light and easy to learn, teach, and play, yet still maintains a good amount of thought and strategy. Each turn is satisfying, there is no downtime because everyone takes their actions at once. The first few times playing through is awesome getting a sense of all the different buildings. It's often hard to choose which to building to lay down, as you have to pay for it with other building cards in your hands(the buildings double as 'gold'). Just plain fun, hard to turn down this one.

RATING: 7
Very addictive when I first played this game. But it becomes stale after playing about 80-100 times.

2-player is tight and plays very differently than 3 or 4 players.
3-player is not very balanced and not much room for different paths to victory.
4-player is more balanced and there are multiple viable paths to victory.

The short game length makes many cards useless because there will not be enough time to get the proper return on investment.

RATING: 7

In my opinion San Juan is very underhyped - it's a great game on its own and it's defintely worth knowing.

RATING: 7
Card and much lighter version of Puerto Rico - select roles to maximise your cards from which to select and place buildings into play and which also represent the currency of the game. Plays quickly and scales well up to 4 players. There is an element of luck in the draw of the cards with some being better than others, but the deck will likely cycle a couple of times in a game giving everyone enough access to cards and the games are quick. Good components.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
San Juan uses the now-traditional "everyone-chooses-a-different-phase" technique common to El Grande, Race For the Galaxy and many others.  Since this is meant to at least slightly mimic real life, I object to the idea that an action chosen by one player can not be chosen by another player.  If you don't get your economy (number of cards being received and used each turn) going early, you may as well forget it.  This is a much simpler and fairer game than it's parent game Puerto, which is even more dependent on an early working economy and therefore not worth ever playing.  While it appears kind of balanced, in reality you need cards that go well together.  The chance of that are small.  Also, since there are very few ways to earn victory points, you are dependent on getting those cards that earn you large points.  There is a large enough deck that you can almost entirely miss seeing any of those cards for the entire game.  Some cards are way too strong and should be diluted.  While you can have fun playing San Juan, it doesn't measure up to my standards of fairness and thus I tend to balk at playing it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Plays well for two.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The primary innovation of Puerto Rico, the role selection system, is less exciting and less important here.  San Juan is much more about hand management: getting a good influx of cards, choosing which cards to build and in what order, and knowing which cards to give up and which ones to save.  Some cards work well for almost anyone and others require other synergistic cards or specific strategies in order to be effective.  There's a bit of a learning curve in figuring out what works and what doesn't, but overall the game is more forgiving and less intimidating for beginners than Puerto Rico.  The central mechanism of cards-as-buildings-or-cash works well, although it creates the need for an awful lot of drawing, discarding, and shuffling. 

My chief complaint is that San Juan feels disappointingly solitaire-ish in comparison to Puerto Rico.  Yeah, your role choice will have some effect on the others.  But mostly the same roles are selected each turn because there are fewer roles overall and no incentive to choose the neglected ones.  This reduces player interaction and makes each turn feel the same as the last.  The other factors that create interaction in Puerto Rico are mostly missing here:  there's no competition for ships, an unlimited supplies of goods, no goods spoilage, unlimited use of the trading house, and no commonly available pool of buildings.  What we're left with is a game that's all about managing your hand, finding the powerful cards and/or the right combos, and building an engine to churn and play as many cards as possible.  San Juan was pleasant for several games, but I think I'm done with it.  A final note: the Library should be removed for two-player matches.

[Jan 2008 - rating lowered one more point after seeing some of the same ideas executed so much better in Race for the Galaxy]

RATING: 8
We've settled in on removing the Libaries and reducing the Guild Hall bonus to 1 point per Production card. It now feels that the number of strategies has opened up and choice of strategies depends on what cards you're getting and how your opponent is building. Essentially, it feels like a richer 2-player game with the modifications we've made. 

We've now played it over 100 times and we're still nearly even with neither of us ever getting much more than 4 games ahead. We have made one alteration to the rules: The Guild Hall only gives One point (instead of two) for each resource card. Otherwise the Guild Hall was too powerful. 

We've now played it nearly 40 times and it's our current favorite. My wife and I are dead even at 20 games a piece. 

Very cool first two games. It satisfied all the criteria and was lots of fun. And it totally smokes the similar Citadels as a 2-player game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Plays differently enough to Puerto Rico to definitely make it worthwhile having both. Puerto Rico can be fiddly to set up whereas this is very easy and plays quicker too. Doesn't quite have the same depth as it's sister game though.

RATING: 7

Each turn, you pick a role, get the bonus it provides and the main action while the other players only do the main action if they want.

The downside of this game is that you really need to be four players to enjoy it fully.

It's one of the few simple games I like.

RATING: 8
I like that this game is relatively easy to pick up and teach to others. But, it takes many, many plays to master. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
The simple and well designed system, based on role selection and supported by many different buildings, manages to translate some of the "Puerto Rico" experience to the card game format. At the same time, it feels a little like "Citadels" without the messing with the other players. Using the building cards themselves as money is a nice idea and creates some agonizing decisions. However, the game still has the luck inherent to card draws. You may get behind or take a good lead depending on the cards you get early in the game, and a few can be too powerful. Reshuffling may be annoying, and the theme is still extremely dull, of course. At least this time we get pictures for the buildings.

RATING: 6.5
I played this game many times, just to find out that it is pretty much luck-dependent. Also, the main part is decided by your starting cards. If you try to get around your starting cards, you lose time and will lose the game.

Also, there are only 2 strategys available, using production or buildings and the buildings have a slight advantage. All in all, it depends on the cards you will draw and got in your starting hand.

It´s not a bad game in any way, but it´s not as deep as it may seem at first glance.

RATING: 7.5
I suspect that I was expecting too much from this game. I finally got to play it this weekend and to be honest I was rather underwhelmed. 

There is even less player interaction than in Puerto Rico and because you can only build from a very limited collection of cards there is a significant degree of luck of the draw.

After my first playings of PR I was constantly thinking about ideas for strategies. San Juan on the other hand has left me thinking if I can possibly use it as a way to get people to play PR.

I have now played several more times, while there is some strategy there is a lot of luck of the draw. There are some cards that I have never seen in my hand. 

After some more plays I have uprated my opinion slightly. This is a game I am happy to play but I still feel that there is not a huge amount of control from a player point of view.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good game with limited choices.   The strategy you take seems dictated by the cards you get.  This minor detraction doesn't really take away from a fast easy and fun game that is actually pretty deep.  The game doesn't play like a card game, it plays more like a simplified version of a heavier euro (which it is) because there are several different resources to manage.  The brilliant thing about this game is that the several different resources are all represented by the same cards, just used in different ways.  A clever design.  Most of my 100+ unlogged plays have been online.  Only issue is that sometimes it feels like there is a right way and a wrong way to play the game, and once you figure out the mathematically correct way to do it, you are done.  The game is then decided by luck between players who know how to play well.  Good game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Follows the theme and some of the fundamental mechanics of its big brother, Puerto Rico, while still managing to stand out as a good game in its own right.  Unfortunately, Race for the Galaxy does everything that San Juan does, only better, so I won't really play it anymore unless I need a lighter, gateway-type game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
We almost always play with a house rule that the Guild Hall is worth 2 points per *different* production building -- so a maximum of 10 points if you build the sugar, coffee, tobacco, and silver in addition to the original indigo plants.  That puts it in line with the other 6-buildings, which have similar max values.

Rules question:  can you draw a card for the Poor House in the turn that you build it?  The rules explicitly note that you can't draw a card for the Carpenter on the turn that you build it, but there is no explicit note for the Poor House.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Some tough choices to make depending on the cards drawn.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
While not as gamey as it's bigger sibling Puerto Rico or offer a decision tree as rich as Glory to Rome or Race through the Galaxy, San Juan still stands out on its own. What it does better than the game mentioned above is that it is a much more relaxed endeavour, it is simple, as well as far easier to introduce while still being gamey and have substance.

My only criticism of the game is that the balance heavily swings towards civil (i.e., purple) buildings in the two player game -- this, in turn means that players not in the know or players whose draws don't match the dominant strategy don't stand as strong a chance to make it out on top. However, the game is not terribly long to play -- so this type of bad luck is not damning but rather an invitation to try one's had at it again.

Update: July 4th 2015 -------------------------------------
The expansion buildings address my only criticism of the game (i.e., mono-purple) by making diverse paths not only feasible, but also fun!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[Initial Impression: 7]
Obviously, it's the same basic system as Puerto Rico, only with far less bits and fewer ways to end the game (exactly one, when one player builds 12 buildings).  It feels very odd to use cards both as money, as produced goods, and as buildings to be built, but makes for some tense decisions.  The dearth of cards early in the game makes the prospector much more worthwhile than in Puerto Rico.  All in all, a nice portable version that captures much of the Puerto Rico experience.  Scales well with different player counts, and is a very good game with two players.

RATING: 6
This is a neat, lighter theming of Puerto Rico.  I like the art on the cards, and the mechanism are fun.  In many aspects, this is a good introduction to Puerto Rico.  I also like its portability.

The game is a little complex for new players. It confuses those who have never seen card games where the cards can have multiple uses.  In this aspect, it is a neat resource management game and not strictly card collection.
