=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A pseudo-streamlined version of Puerto Rico, with some unique features guaranteed to confuse newcomers (like me). The role selection is pretty much the same (the chooser gets a "bonus" for picking the role). The buildings are somewhat different, staying with the theme of PR, but with different capabilities. The cards themselves can be used like currency (to buy buildings), or represent goods (which can be turned into cards), or they become buildings. This aspect had me initially befuddled (similar to Glory to Rome), but after a few plays got used to it. The pace is quick, the rules are simple, but the strategy is deep for a card-driven game. Not as intense as Dominion, but a nice change of pace.

Update (05/25/09): Finally won my first game after playing this on-and-off sporadically for nearly a year. Game is compact and portable, enough so that we could whip out a quick game at the airport. Still, getting to know the advantages of specific buildings is key, which means newbies will get destroyed in their first few games. This, coupled with the "card can be a resource, money, or building" mechanic, may not be as accessible as a gateway game for newbies. People familiar with Puerto Rico will fare better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Take [i]Puerto Rico[/i] and boil off all the fussy crap.  What's left in the bottom of the cauldron is a gooey tar of condensed fun.  Roll the tar out and cut it into rectangles and you have [i]San Juan[/i].

This one wins out over its older brother in three very important areas—it's accessible, portable and short.  In the time it would take you to play a single game of [i]Puerto Rico[/i] (not counting rules explanation (shudder)) you could play three games of this [i]including[/i] an overview of the rules.  [i]San Juan[/i] has the potential to see far more table time than [i]PR[/i].  That make it clearly superior in my book.  Recommended.

Component shot after a vigorous "gravity sorting":

[imageid=2643926 small]

RATING: 7
I know a few people who are not fans of this game, but I really like to play it. It's fairly quick, and a variety of strategies will work...despite what some people say or think. It's about watching what the other players are doing, manipulating the deck, sticking to or abandoning strategies as appropriate, etc. I have seen folks run away with the game using at least 4 different strategies. 

I have come to a decision that SanJuan, while once one of my hot games, has a huge luck element. I consider myself to be a pretty good player, but if you are not getting cards...you are SOL. Therefore I have downgraded the game. I like game s in which I have more control. I will still play it, and probably enjoy it...but it is no longer on my hot list.

And after playing some more, I have raised it again. I just think its playability for me is there.

RATING: 8
Another game I've played hundreds of times with the computer version.  This is a very fun game.  It is based on Puerto Rico and is a lite and quick card version of that masterpiece.  The only problem I have with this game is that due to the limited number of Guild Hall cards, it is way too risky to go for a win via the production strategy.  Essentially there is only one sure fire strategy to win and that involves the violet buildings combined with City Hall/Palace/Triumphal Arch.  It then comes down to a lot of luck as far as who gets the right cards at the right time.  But, it's still lots of fun for me, as my hundreds of plays make obvious.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
THE NUMBER ONE game of 2007 in our household. San Juan caught my brain like no other game has since the second Heroes of Might and Magic PC game in the late 1990s. What really impressed me about San Juan was how much I enjoyed the game whereas I think that Puerto Rico is way, way over-rated on the 'geek. I know I am in the minority, but PR just does not do it for me. San Juan, however...

I played San Juan more than any other game in my library in 2007. 2-4 players? 45-minute playing time? Strategic gameplay? Sign me up!

The artwork - while simple - is just right. I love the color choices and the look of the buildings throughout the deck. Every week it seems as if we find another path to victory, another way the cards can combine in new and interesting ways.

I typically choose not to play my analog board games on the PC. San Juan was one of my two exceptions (Ticket To Ride being the other... and I like this game better).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It amazes me that San Juan can feel so much like Puerto Rico in spite of the fact that it has an enormous luck factor, whereas Puerto Rico leaves almost nothing to chance.  In spite of the occasional game loss due to poor draws, I still enjoy San Juan.  It plays relatively quickly, has multiple paths you can take to victory, and the addition of luck means that games vary wildly from play to play, so games have a lot of variety to them.  San Juan is cheaper than a lot of other games, and it's incredibly portable - I put my entire set into one of the thicker CCG deck boxes.  In spite of the luck factor I heartily recommend this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
One of my favorites. Plays more quickly than Puerto Rico and I like the randomness of the cards drawing (in addition to how the game uses the same building cards as resources and much more) more than the "perfect information" of it's "big brother". The only flaw of the game, if you wish to call it that, is that it is more a multiplayer solitaire, since the only way to affect your neighbours is to take a role he desires. Still, it's fun to play not-so-confrontational game occasionally since many of our regular games are pretty cut-throat.

RATING: 7
San Juan is an improvement on Puerto Rico as far as I'm concerned.  Still, the game is pretty boring and maybe a bit oversimplified.  There also appears to be a smidgen of luck of the draw as I couldn't get any of the cool buildings other people were throwing down all the time on my first play.  The game isn't bad, just not all that great either.  It appears to be a middle of the road under-achiever.

-But hey, the girlfriend likes it...*grumble grumble*

Update:  This game has grown on me more, but it still feels like there's a lack in variety of strategies...  I can usually only play a couple games of this a week max or it begins to feel way too repetitive and deterministic.

Lots of strategies, relatively short but in-depth gameplay. Great game for people new to gaming and for seasoned gamers.

For those of you who know RFTG: yes, it seems a little like a little brother but I think they differ enough to have them both on the shelf. Also, you can use San Juan as an introduction to the flow of RFTG (without the intimidating icons), or as a completely different game for a different crowd.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Dec15: Picked it up again now that it comes with the expansions.  Plan on using it for more family/gamer intro purposes.

Aug17:

It's not RftG, but it's still damn good.  More approachable as well.

RATING: 8

If one person doesn't get the Library, it seems crippling.  The bonus building that gives 2 points for each production building also seems too strong.  We modified the rules for that to be 2 points for each DIFFERENT production building.  Still with those mods, it's a great game.

RATING: 7
A very solid card game, nice mechanics with the role selection that presents some tricky decisions.  Picking which cards to discard or keep can be game changing and knowing when to choose each role is crucial.  It can get very interesting once you have developed your tableau a bit, and you have some opportunities for combo-making.

Only downer is that it is a bit solitaire-y, the role selection affects your opponent but the game does lack interaction - but only a bit. This is a very minor complaint, this game is great fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Nicely-themed card game, with the feel of a strategic board game. Like other card games, it plays relatively quickly and features quite a significant element of luck. However, the players' strategies and tactical play are significantly more important than chance in determining the outcome of any game. The more I play San Juan, the more I appreciate how well the mechanisms work together. The luck involved in receiving good scoring cards can, however, still be a little off-putting.
UPDATE: Well, San Juan certainly has a lot of staying power. I'm approaching my twentieth game over the course of almost five years and I'm still happy to play it.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I have now played this game several times, but ONLY two player.  As a two player game, this game plays very well and provides a number of different tactics/ build decisions.  I haven't yet played it with more than two.  I don;t understand those that attack this game as simply a "weak" "light" version of Puerto Rico.  It is lighter than Puerto Rico.  However,even thought the games share the same designer and theme, the actual mechanics are very different from PR.  While the games share a modified version of the "job" system, the jobs in San Juan are all about card manipulation of some sort.  San Juan is all about the tempo of your building construction and maximizing card values and tactically has nothing in common with PR.    It just seems that many who are negative on this game were expecting "PR: the travel edition" and were upset when they got a different game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Finally got to play the computer version of this, so far focusing on the 2 player version. Damn AI was hard to beat for the first 5 games! Challenging is good=fun. It is lacking interaction (the game in general as it feels your just playing your own game really)and there is some luck in the draw, however you need both good strategic and tactical play to do well. You do need to pay attention to the other players.
 
Update: After several more plays this feels more like a race now, basically who can build smartest the fastest. Still fun and addictive. Really want to try PR now...

Update: I prefer PR by a big margin over this however I noticed San Juan with 3 players is pretty good and better than with only 2. Something about the card distribution, turn orders, etc just makes it feel more like a game to me over the 2 player which seems more like a race. This is still a good option with any number if you lack time for the real deal (PR).

aka PUERTO RICO KAARTSPEL. Bij Pascal, 29/12/2015. Puerto Rico zonder veel toeters en bellen. Alle gebouwen staan op kaarten die aan de achterkant meteen ook als "geld" met een waarde 1 tellen. Principe van rollen kiezen (met bijhorend privilege) blijft behouden (goudzoeker, productie, bouwmeester, handelaar, soort burgemeester (naam vergeten)). Er zijn productiegebouwen en paarse gebouwen. Wanneer iemand 12 gebouwen heeft gebouwd, is het spel gedaan. Goed spel, dat snel klaarligt. Het originele Puerto Rico blijft echter het summum.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
San Juan is considered by many to be an inferior take on a tableau-building, role-selection card game compared to Race for the Galaxy, but I prefer this lighter approach where the focus is more on executing one or more of a limited set of strategies through optimal timing rather than understanding a plethora of possibilities that are not obvious to all but experienced players. As a result, it has a much shorter learning curve. It does sacrifice some depth to achieve this and can sometimes be frustrating in the occasional game where luck of the draw has it in for a particular player, but these flaws are tolerable for a 30-45 minute card game that is, on the whole, an enjoyable experience with just enough depth to make it fun as a filler or a featured game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Plays well with two.  It's fast and easy to teach.  I'm not convinced that there's a wide variety of strategies available, but that doesn't seem to detract from it too much.

I dropped this rating from 8.5 to 5.5, because of Race for the Galaxy.  I just see myself wanting to play Race more often, although San Juan will still be travelling with me to all family gatherings.

If you hate Race for the Galaxy, but want a Puerto Rico Lite then you should check this game out.

RATING: 5
Light-weight card game based on Puerto Rico. I am not too impressed with the game. Part of it is probably being spoiled by Puerto Rico, but overall San Juan seemed too simplistic (one-dimensional), repetitive and, well, 'forgiving' compared with PR. However, at the moment I can't see it as a satisfactory "light weight PR" substitute, and with so many other nice light games to choose from, I have difficulty seeing myself playing this a lot. The game does work better with more than two players though.

RATING: 5
2013-07-05

Initial Rating: 5.5 (July 2013)

An ok game, although too light for my taste. I (obviously) see the resemblance to RFTG, however, I thought they were more similar. I don’t particularly like Puerto Rico, so I don’t expect much from San Juan. The theme is awful (for me) as is the game art, neither inspire me to play the game. At least you have some interesting choices from time to time but I found the game to be (more or less) obvious.

I dislike how you never know for how much you can sell your goods, also it seems there are too few roles.

Bottom line, San Juan is much more easier (and accessible, its only advantage) than RFTG, however for me both games are mutually exclusive so I don’t think I will play San Juan a lot, I will continue to play RFTG, a very superior game in my book.

Current Rating: 5.5
[hr]
2013-12-09

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is almost as good as Puerto Rico and easier to pick up. Plus, it plays with two.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Each player has a hand of cards which are different buildings and which double as money. To build a building you have to discard its cost in cards. Some buildings generate income, others make using your cards more efficient, or are just worth bonus points. Given the cards on the table, players take it in turns to select one of the remaining "roles" which then means [u]everyone[/u] now can build, or generate resources, or sell resources, or whatever the role says.

Only played 2P so far. We like it. I prefer it to its "big brother" Puerto Rico... there's more going on in San Juan yet it moves more quickly.

RATING: 7.5
Great game. I prefer SJ to RfG. Don't see how all those extra icons in RtG give you deeper play rather than just more complexity. I like the tension of never having enough cards in hand to "pay" for what you want and having that sinking feeling as you glance what your opponents are doing! Some of the cards seem too strong though. Biggest defect is that certain strategies are somewhat obvious, game plays itself a bit. 3p seems the sweet spot; for 2p, Glory to Rome better.
Update: As I've played GtR more, SJ of course seems simplistic. But that hasn't eliminated my desire to play.  If anything, SJ is solidified in its place when I want a quick simple game rather than an epic battle.  GtR or RftG or Eminent Domain don't "fire" SJ just because they share the same core mechanism--no more than a Ferrari fires a Corolla.

RATING: N/A
[b][url=http://www.spieldesjahres.de/cms/front_content.php?idcat=8]2004 Spiel des Jahres Recommended[/url][/b]

[thing=166669][/thing]

A card game based on Puerto Rico. The pack of 110 cards consists of production buildings (indigo, sugar, tobacco, coffee, and silver) and violet buildings that grant special powers or extra victory points. Cards from the hand can be either built or used as money to build something else. Cards from the deck are used to represent goods produced by the production buildings, in which case they are left face-down. A seven-card hand limit is enforced once per round. This new edition of San Juan contains the additional buildings from the previously available expansion but not the event cards. It also contains a new building not previously available in any version: The Hut. This building grants a card when nothing was sold in the trader phase.

Players: 2, 3, 4
Time: 45−60 min
Mechanics: [property=2040][/property], [property=2004][/property], [property=2079][/property]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Despite its commonalities with Puerto Rico, I don't feel I know this game well enough to rate it after one play.  San Juan brings to the forefront what was perhaps the only aspect of Puerto Rico that I didn't care much for, the myriad special properties and powers of the buildings, while greatly simplifying my favorite part of PR, the process of growing, selling, and shipping crops; it also feels too luck-dependant for a game that is so dependent on planning.  Still, the strength of the role-selection mechanism and the tactical choices offered by discarding some cards to "build" (play) others made for a fun game.  At this point, San Juan is a tentative '7', based more on my enjoyment of my one game than my (lack of) desire to play it again.

[color=green]
LAST PLAY: 2010
[/color][color=blue]
It's a light version of Puerto Rico.

A nice thing of this game is that you can represent everything with the cards: buildings, goods, VPs,... you don't need any extra counter.

In the other hand, I think it doesn't work fine for two people, there are always enough production buildings and it is so easy to get cards.

It's not a bad game, but I prefer Puerto Rico. A good choice for this game could be Race For the Galaxy.[/color]

RATING: N/A
[***Fantasy Flight sleeve size: Standard European - Purple (FFS04, 50/pack) - (2-5/16” x 3-9/16" - 59 x 92mm)***]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is a winner.  My 8 rating is cautious and may go up with more plays.  Played with people aged 9 to 61 and everyone has liked it.  The use of cards as money and buildings and commodities is makes this a landmark design.  No DIRECT player interaction, but your decisions are heavily influenced by what the other players are doing - there is LOADS of indirect interaction and you really have to keep an eye on your opponents.  This is no multiplayer solitaire with an auction overlaid as a lame interaction mechanism - there is real player-vs-player tension here.  2 player games a fun and quick but can be scripted (and take out the libraries!) but in 4 player the players really must adapt to what others are doing.  Only complaint is that there are a couple of horribly under-powered buildings - the crane and the archive are bad and the sugar mill is not good either.  Rating raised to 9 after 50-60 games.  Fantastic.
Update:  four player San Juan is probably broken - fourth player really cannot win against competent opponents.  Three player is also difficult for the third player but not as much.  Tough to think of a good fix, however - the alternative starting hand rules are probably not quite a big enough help.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.4
One of my favorite card games. Very fun. My wife beats my pants off almost every time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Unlike many gamers, I actually played Race for the Galaxy before I played San Juan. I didn't care for it much. The lapsed CCGer in me wanted to love the rich card combinations, but I found the "discard cards in order to play other cards" mechanic a massive barrier to my brand of strategic enjoyment. I realize that you can play the game in a zen-like state of openness, taking the opportunities as they come, but that's not really my style. Perhaps more importantly, I was turned off by the simultaneous role selection of RftG, because it took much of the focus off of clever card play and put it on inferring your opponents' probable actions, not so you could response in a normal sense, but so you could piggy-back on their roles and get more done.

So, San Juan. It doesn't have simultaneous role selection, which already makes it a markedly better game for me. The combinations available are also much less complicated, which I judge to be a better suited to a game that cycles cards directly into the discard pile before they see the light of play. Thing is, Puerto Rico is such a quick and smoothly flowing game that I can't see why I'd ever play this instead. Glory to Rome, my pick in last month's list, runs circles around this game when it comes to using cards both as buildings and building materials. In the end, San Juan seems merely unnecessary.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is excellent for two players or more.  My strategies are evolving with experience.  My wife and I love it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My gateway into Eurogames.  Played it to death for a while.  Great mechanics, love the "cards are everything" mechanic and the role-selection mechanic.  But I've played it so much now that I know even if you beat everyone with your "engine", it still boils down to being lucky enough to draw City Hall, Guild Hall, Castle and/or Triumphal Arch w/ all 3 monuments.  That kills the game for me...too few real victory paths.  Rating:6

Update: After one play of the Alea Treasure Chest expansion, I think it fixes the problems I have with the game.  Rating: 8 - and if it stands to repeated plays, it could easily go to 9

She would actually prefer Blue Moon, because reading the distributed rules on the cards is part of the spirit of the game, and earning VPs through building guildhalls and plantations pales in comparison to mutants, dragons and hosing your opponent with a massive fire strike!

(Based on online play, I personally think the quick play and simulation of the Puerto Rico economy through hand size are great concepts.)

RATING: 9
Surprisingly deep. After my first 10 plays (against the computer), I thought luck was the dominant factor. After 700 plays, I'm fascinated that there are still several BSW players that routinely beat me. Not that I think I'm a particularly skilled gamer, but I would have thought 700 plays would have been more than enough to reach the point where luck determines the outcome between similarly experienced players.

The number of players changes the game significantly, but it's excellent at all counts. It might take the nominal 45 minutes in your first 4-player game, but with a table of experienced players it becomes a meaty filler, 20 minutes max.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Was aware of the game, but it wasn't really on my list... until I picked it up brand new at a moving sale for $13! Hoping that it becomes one of those great (and cheap!) surprises for us.
--
After a TERRIBLE first attempt at trying to learn/teach the game, that ended 4 turns in (more due to the state of mind/health of the players than the game), we finally got around to playing again and I think it was safe to say that all involved loved it. The mechanics, honestly, do take a little time to wrap your head around - but once you get it, it's a lot of fun.

What's more, I'm hoping that the positive response to San Juan leads to more games of Puerto Rico and (fingers crossed) Race for the Galaxy. Whether or not that actually happens, I think we'll still be playing San Juan for a while to come.

RATING: 6
I've enjoyed the Java version of this card game for a while now. The game plays quite well in person and is an excellent quick fix for that Puerto Rico urge. As usual with card games you can lay the blame of loss on a poor card draw so this really does hold it back. The speed of the game means alot of this luck can be ignored as you can always just pick up, shuffle and play again. A good fun game. A little too involved to be considered a filler. Scales pretty well.
As with Puerto Rico, it suffers from having no mechanics to aggravate the runaway leader.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A much lighter version of Puerto Rico. Captures many of the same elements but is different enough to not feel exactly like the same game. Plays quick (under an hour) once you get familiar with everything. Very fun. Plays well with two players, but much better with more. The only knock against the game I have is the trading. If no one else is utilizing the producer/trader rolls, you'll have a tough time pulling it off by yourself. On the other hand, if everyone is utilizing those rolls and you haven't had a chance to get any production buildings down, you'll be left out and possibly hindered. Worth having in your collection for sure! My rating is for 3+ players. It's an 8 for a 2 player game.

RATING: 9
I love this game. It is well balanced and versatile with 2, 3 or 4 players. My wife and I always enjoy this as a 2-player in the quiet of the evening after the kids are down. I introduced it to my neighbor in a 3-player game (also with my wife) and he immediately declared it his favorite game. (I have since taught him Puerto Rico and now he won't play SJ anymore.) My wife and I like that you can just plop down and start playing San Juan (and it plays much quicker with fewer choices to make each turn). We also played this with another couple on our street as a 4-player. They caught on very quickly and her husband ended up winning the game! It was close up to the last round when he got a 6 violet down that pushed him ahead of me. It's just a great game, easy enough to learn, with lots of ways to go after the win.

RATING: 7

My only wish is that the cards were a bit sturdier, and that the game came with scoring chips rather than pad and paper - the Java version displays scores for players progressively through the game, so you can make decisions based on the score rather than a guesstimate.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A role selection card game inspired by Puerto Rico. The novel key mechanic is that every card has a cost to play and to pay that cost you must discard other cards. This forces you to constantly evaluate which cards to play and which to give up and ensures interesting and difficult decisions throughout the game. This game is quick, easy to learn, and fun.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
San Juan is a great resource management card game. If you are looking for something similar to Puerto Rico, go somewhere else, as they don't have anything in common, aside the license.

In opposite to Puerto Rico, San Juan is a very tactical game, so the brain burning of the first is substituted by the simple yet agonizing decisions that need to be taken each turn. As a card game, luck makes an impact, but isn't dramatic.

Interaction in San Juan is low and and completely indirect. From time to time players will be able to affect their opponents with certain moves, but nothing too drastic. Things like not picking a role which would benefit them or holding buildings which would benefit them most.

This one and Race for the Galaxy are frequently compared, and not without reason: they play very similar. I'm more fond of race, though. Mainly because the interaction in Race, despite being even more indirect, is more frequent and meaningful than in San Juan. It's way easier to understand the depths of San Juan than those of Race, so it's usually better to start off with this one.

San Juan is a fun tactical card game. And scales surprisingly well too! While you do need to adapt your playingstyle, it can be played with any number of players. I do prefer it with two or three though, due to the greater degree of control.

Rating: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Optimal number of players:
:thumbsup:2~3

[i]To have more information on how I rate games, [geekurl=/user/Kodeir]go to my profile[/geekurl][/i]

RATING: 5
Puerto Rico light? Sort of. But there's very little player interaction, and the buildings available in your hand are more or less random. Some strategy is involved, but this game completely lacks the charm and the payoff of a good strategy that Puerto Rico offers.

Lately I've been getting back into this thanks to the Treasure Chest expansions. They don't change the game that much, but that's a good thing.

San Juan is a good airport or café game.

RATING: 8.5
It's fairly simple to teach, but very interesting to play. It's actually more complicated than most of the gateways (Ticket to Ride, Carcassone, and Settlers of Catan are all simpler to learn), but still quite teachable, especially since the cards are quite explicit about what they do. So I think it fits a good niche.  

A lot of people say that RftG is just flat out better (and more complicated).  I also prefer RftG, but I'll need more plays of San Juan to decide whether it's relative simplicity is being mistaken for being less deep.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
[Original] This card game is a must have in all game collections. Although based on the widely acclaimed Puerto Rico, it is its own game. The similarity between it and its progenitor is obvious in that: (a) there are roles to choose from each turn (in this case 5 roles: Builder, Councillor, Producer, Prospector, and Trader), (b) many of the building perform similar functions, and (c) the game ends when a player builds his/her twelfth building. However, the differences are equally obvious in that: (1) the game is much shorter (due to faster play), (2) there a new buildings that the original Puerto Rico does not have, and (3) the strategies are very different. [Note: Some buildings from San Juan do appear in the 2004 expansion for Puerto Rico.] Finally, it is important to note that this game is best when played more than once. Being familiar with the different cards ("buildings") is necessary for improved play. Give the game a try, but please play it more than once before rating it here on BGG--you'll be glad that you did. Have fun building your own version of old San Juan... I always do!

[2008.Mar.29] Still a very good game, but now that I have played Race for the Galaxy a handful of times San Juan suffers minor bump (downwards) in my ratings.

:star::star::star::star::nostar:

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
San Juan condenses the Puerto Rico experience, taking PR's coolest feature (the buildings) and making them the main show.  It also cuts out a lot of the procedural junk that made some of PR feel like work to me -- planting the corn fields, drafting the colonists.

Unfortunately, though, it also cuts out the major zero-sum aspects of PR -- the trading house and crowded ships.  That's a shame, because if Seyfarth had ported those over to this game I think it could have been great.  As it is, it's merely "pretty good."

It ends up reminding me less of PR and more of "Citadels".  And I think it compares poorly with Citadels -- they're both building races, but in Citadels you can directly affect your opponent:  assasinate him so he loses his turn, steal his gold, take his cards, blow up his buildings.  There's nothing at all like that in this game.

In "San Juan", it's mainly a contest of timing.  Choose to build when your opponent is low on cards... choose to produce when his production houses are already full, stuff like that.  It's not bad, and sometimes I like a low-conflict gaming experience like that.  The CCG-like interactions with the building are fun to explore and discover.  It's clear that there a few different strategies available for winning here, but equally clear that the ceiling for these possibilities is rather low.

The cleverest thing about this game is the "cards as everything" approach... I'd like to see that imported into another game because it makes everything run so cleanly and intuitively.  I'll have a fair amount of fun with this game, but it's clear that burn-out can't be all that far off.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Sometimes I play it solo on computer as an engaging time waster and other times I play it with friends as a meaty filler. It's a satisfyingly quick approximation of Puerto Rico and a good gaming experience in its own right.

San Juan + Expansion (adds 1 of each type) production buildings:
11 Indigo
9 Sugar
9 Coffee
9 Tobacco
9 Silver

2nd Editions changes:
Bank cost decreased from 4 to 3.
Prefecture cost increased from 3 to 4.
Gold mine now adds the lowest cost card instead of any card.
Guild hall reduced from 2 points per production building to 1 point per building and now also provides 1 point for each different type of production building.
Newly added Hut: "In the trader phase, the owner of a hut draws one card from the supply if no good was sold by any player during this phase."
One less Sugar mill included (8 total).
Includes new buildings plus 1 of each type of production building from expansion set but not event cards.
Improved iconography and art.

Thoughts on 2nd edition: The artwork on the second edition looks great. It's a shame the new Hut card is a bit of a disappointment. While the Event cards in the expansion can be fun, they won't be missed in this edition. Increasing the Prefecture was a good call. I understand the reason for the change to the Gold Mine, but it would have been better to receive one of the cards at random instead of the lowest value one every time. The change to the Guild Hall seems reasonable to prevent scoring lots of points for multiple cheap production buildings.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Great Game

RATING: 6
[gameid=28143]-lite.

An okay game that uses the same character selection as Puerto Rico. The theme is pretty thin and the strategy is fairly basic. Decide which "6 building"  you are going for, then build cards that work with with/for that building.

This echoes the comments of others (I forgot who) that state San Juan takes away the multiple paths to victory that Puerto Rico has. Race for the Galaxy solves the issue by having victory point chips, which allows for multiple paths to victory.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[GAMEID=8217] actually feels like more than just a card game.  There is a sense of actually building your colony and you can see your new buildings spread out in front of you.  Each building gives you special abilities, so there is a lot of potential for making efficient card combinations, so it was right up our alley.  The mechanism of using cards to do everything from buildings, money, and trade goods is unique, but facilitates rapid card turnover.  As a result, you get to go through quite a few cards, so the luck doesn't seem as dominant as you can go through the deck quickly.  Since the goods used unseen cards, it also prevented card counting, something neither of us was too interested in.  In order to be a good player, you have to tailor your game to the cards that you [i]do[/i] get---and it's quite balanced where you can go with a production/Guild Hall route or a violet building/City Hall route or even a mix of the two and stay competitive.  

The game also works quite well with two players.  With two, it's a little easier to get the role that you need, so the game is more of a race/efficiency game.  With more players, there is more chance to use the roles as a denial to other players, so the game does feel different with different numbers of players, which I think is a good thing.  Although, since each player gets to perform the action, there feels like less of a runaway leader problem as well.  

Sadly we also downloaded one of the [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/filepage/19840]San Juan PC versions[/url] here and ended up overdosing on it.  It became our essential "Solitaire" game to play on the computer whenever we had free time.  As a result, it somewhat soured us on face to face play, especially since we were used to the much faster computer version.  [GAMEID=8217] is a game that definitely feels like it deserves an expansion to spice it up.

Update:  We ended up getting [GAMEID=28143] in a trade and we love it!  See above for more details.  Sadly in the end, [GAMEID=28143] has completely replaced [GAMEID=8217] for us.  Although, I think that it would have been much more intimidating to learn without having played [GAMEID=8217] first.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
After many a 15-20 games of this, I am only now just starting to win every once in a while. Kirk established a sound strategy early on involving building hundreds (okay, more like ten) production buildings, and acquiring a library ASAP to maximize his turns. 

That said, there are many paths to victory in this game, which makes replayability pretty good. 

Libraries, in our opinion, are so amazingly beneficial that if both players don't acquire them around the same time, the game quickly becomes unbalanced. We usually remove the Libraries from the deck before play now. We also change a couple of the cards - Guild Hall, for example, only adds a single point for each production building (rather than the original two points). Otherwise it's almost a certainty that whoever gets hold of a Guild Hall (always Kirk, somehow) will win the game. At 1 point per production building, it seems a little more balanced.

I feel like this one is slightly more hyped than I would expect, but I do like playing it a lot.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.9
After repeated play, this one started to feel a little one-dimensional.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played only on BSW.  A decent card game, but too many of the decisions seem pretty obvious.  I'm not saying that there is no skill involved in the game - there's actually a fair amount - but the game just doesn't engage me.  Good for an occasional play, though.

UPDATE: Bumping this up to a 7, ironically just as I am about to get its sibling, Race for the Galaxy. I've now played SJ a fair bit on BSW, and it has grown on me a little. My biggest issue with San Juan is that all of the scoring methods depend on having a powerful card-drawing engine. This makes every play feel very similar, even if I am pursuing a different strategy. SJ needs another element to broaden its strategic landscape. I think RftG may offer this "fix", which would be a real blow to my rating for San Juan.

RATING: 7
Fun game, the luck-based Puerto Rico. Needs some rules tweaks for 2 player, where it shines for us (no Library, etc). Since it's quick, the random hosing from bad card draw luck isn't so painful, but it brings the rating down for me.

[2006-03-07] Reduced rtg from 6.5 to 6.0, due to hosing from the random card draw - 4 player game, 6 times through the deck, and I never saw a Single Six Point Card the whole game! Scores: 18 [me], 28, 32, 38. Blech.

3 players is the perfect number for this game.

[2007-03-22] Cautiously raising rating from 5 to 6. Played some 2-player recently, with NO RULES CHANGES, and so far it has played well. This time. I still worry that the random factor will kick in and kill the game again at some point. I stand by my comments on the 3-player (good) and 4-player (sucks) game still.

[2011-03] Have been having a renaissance with this lately. Fun fun. Just the right length, just enough of an engine going on, and each game has been different. Added in the expansion which works well. Upped rating from 6 to 7.

RATING: 6

Most strategies that 'look' good can be easily overcome without any effort.  If I feel like playing this game again I will probably instead just pick up Puerto Rico.  That said the cardstock is quite good and when I play it I do feel like I have options and choices available to me, even if they arn't all as viable as I'd like.

RATING: 8
Really good game that shares similarities with Puerto Rico but that is a completely different game. 

Gameplay is simple if you already have played Puerto. Games are quick, each games is different depending on player number and on the cards you draw. 

There is luck in the game but it can be mitigated by good play. I really like that cards are money and building. It makes each decision really difficult : do I build this big thing and LOSE almost all my hand or do I build this small production for few buck... 

All in all a good game that is also cheap to buy, portable and that is equally good with 2 to 4 players.

RATING: 7
A tableau building game similar to Race for the Galaxy but with a Puerto Rico theme.  It is effectively Puerto Rico, the card game.  I found the game to be a lot of fun and very strategic.  You have to determine what simple buildings you put out to complement your production buildings.  You take roles like Puerto Rico as well that grant small advantages.  I found the game to be great card game that is more accessible than Race for the Galaxy.  A good "next step" game for new players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Shares some mechanics and theme with Puerto Rico, but is a great game in its own right - not just "PR light".  

This is a nice game for something light to play (a filler), or if you want to teach a non-gamer something fairly easy.  Much better with more players.

If you want to play something like SJ, but would like more depth, scalability, and re-playability, see Glory To Rome....a far superior game, but a game that might be too heavy for many.  Race for the Galaxy is also an "upgraded" version of SJ, as it is similar, but adds more depth of play.  Specifically, it makes production more viable as a strategy when playing 2 or 3p as you can directly generate VP's instead of just more cards.

2 players it seems production is an inferior strategy.  I rate it a 6 with two players (still OK), but much better to play with three or four when I would rate it an 7.

RATING: 9
I love this game.
It also has the best box layout (plastic insert) of [u]any[/u] game that I own (well Rum & Pirates comes close, but this is perfection): a place for the cards and the trading tiles, the scorepad and even a special spot for the pencil.

Most of the new expansion cards (from Treasure Chest) are quite good [i]as long as there are a large number of players[/i]. In a 2- or 3-player game, they throw the balance off too much.
I actually like the game better without the expansion cards.

RATING: 9
Despite the fact that I don't like card games in general, this game is really neat. It is important to play it a few times before you judge it. Once you know approximately which cards are in the deck, the game starts to become interesting. Plays very quick and has enough depth to give it a high re-playability score. I personally prefer this game over its mother, the board game Puerto Rico, simply because you can start playing almost immediately (no setup) and it is slightly more simple. Plays wonderfully with 2 players.

RATING: 9
Love this game.  Take everything I like about Puerto Rico, leave behind everything I don't like, add a touch of luck to make it a bit casual, and you get San Juan.  Also, it gives you the same feel as St. Petersburg, but significantly reduces how fiddly it is by combining the money with the cards.

This is one of those games that you don't have to win to take a lot of satisfaction in how you did, the decisions you made etc. to make your little "empire" come together.

Lots of fun.

RATING: N/A
Across The Board 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fantastic card game version of Puerto Rico. I absolutely love this game. I only have the first edition without the expansion so I have only been playing the old basic game. But there is still enough there for me to keep playing it and playing it year after year.

Having said that I think I am about ready to try the expansion buildings and events out. Its just a shame I have to buy the second edition of the whole game to get them.

On your turn you choose a role and perform that action, everyone else then gets to perform that action but not in the extra special way you performed it ... because you are special, so special. You produce / trade / build your buildings and the first to 12 buildings built ends the game (like Roll for the Galaxy, they are all of the same distant related gaming family a bit like a Star Wars plot) . Some give you in game powers, some end game points. I am sure if you are reading this you know how it works. It just works fantastically. Highly recommended to play with gamers of all ages. All of my kids love this.

Keeper. Thinking about getting the second edition just to get the expansion cards.
1  Thumb up tip Hide

RATING: 7.9
Nice card game version of Puerto Rico.  Simpler and quicker than the board game version.  Can be a good dose of luck involved.

The more I play, the less interesting it becomes.  I haven't had the same problem with Puerto Rico (but I haven't played it nearly as much, either).  My problem with SJ is that for 2 players, producing goods isn't really a viable strategy: You NEED to go the City Hall + Prefecture + Quarry route.  With 3, and particularly 4, you can produce goods and still win, so it becomes interesting again (with 3, it can go either way--goods might not really be much of a factor, so again, not that many interesting decisions to make).

The expansion cards are excellent.  They make the deck bigger, so you're not as likely to be able to play your favorite strategy every single time.  They add new life into Trading with 2 or 3 players (with the Customs House), but also maintain a great deck balance.  The Cathedral (which isn't dealt into the deck) is similarly helpful; if you're the unlucky player to never draw the 6 buildings, you can build the Cathedral and capitalize on other players' 6 buildings!  I have nothing bad to say about the new buildings!

Event cards are great, too.  Well-balanced, and give you some interesting options for roles.  The only downside is that the option of event cards can make the Trade/Production strategy less likely even in a 4-player game, since you've often got an event card option.

Kudos to the SJ expansion!  It made my rating for SJ go up quite a bit.

[i]*Own Alea Treasure Chest expansion.[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Love it. Always willing to bring this to the table.

RATING: 8
This is the excellent light version of Puerto Rico!

I also love the fact that the same cards are being used in four ways: as buildings (from your hand to the table), as money (from your hand to the discard pile; to pay for the buildings), as goods (from the draw pile (face down) to a production building), and as victory points (from your hand to the chapel).

The game also plays very well with two!

Edit: After having played 'Race for the Galaxy' a lot, I lowered my rating from 9 to 8 for this game. I'm afraid that 'Race for the Galaxy' took its place...

Besides, imbalances so glaringly obvious that they can be spotted by playing twice would never have passed Stefan Brück; this is an Alea game, after all.

The one quibble I have with the game is  its tendency to resemble a tactical puzzle, and I really don't like that trend in current german games.

Playing RftG has even enhanced my appreciation for this game.

RATING: 8
I originally played this on IOS. It's SO MUCH better in person, without AI players. I think that's true for most games, but considering how much this game rose in my esteem after playing it in person, I would have to say that this game might be (because of the governor action) one of the most important to play with others around a table. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.68
Pro: A solid one mechanic role based gateway card game. One of the first games a gamer can show their non-gamer friends to see what kind of games they like and to show them certain mechanics and how to build "an engine." The mechanics work very well as they are used in other even more popular yet deeper games. Games between equally experienced gamers should be rather competitive. Cheap and travels well.

This game was somewhat written off as trade bait and put to the side. A year later and it keeps sticking around. This is holding up to plays better than some other games. Its greatest crime might be that it isn't Glory to Rome. Some might consider that a good thing.

Rating Potential: 7. I'm not sure it ever gets in the 8 range, but this is really a solid game that holds up so far. I've increased its rating after I bottomed it out. Still a solid gateway into the role selection mechanic but merely playing Glory to Rome showed me there is better out there. How constrained the game is makes for a great gateway, but it leaves it lacking once you are beyond that.

RATING: N/A
Nathalie Rating System: Like it
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Like Puerto-rico lite! This game has similar feel of puerto rico, but has: 2 player rules; quicker rules explanation; fewer parts to lose; quicker set-up; takes less time to play; drawing cards reduces "weak-player syndrome" (BIG problem with PR); and is much more portable. My wife and I have played PR several times and enjoyed it, but we were the weak players and our competitors stomped us... and they took FOREVER in doing it (approx. 2 hours). We played San Juan with same group and the games were much closer, and we even won several times. We introduce this game to our non-gamer friends (those who still think Monopoly is a boardgame...tsk!) and they all enjoy it! Highly recommended!!!

RATING: 5
Puerto Rico kaartspel
New in collection jan. 08 Bought from Lajos.
If you're in for Puerto Rico, but don't want the setup-time, this is an "almost there" alternative.

For me this game is totally obsolete after 2 years: it doesn't come close to the experience of Puerto Rico (the boardgame), and after I played Race for the Galaxy I never played this again.

Now I've found Glory to Rome which is way better than Race for the Galaxy, so where does it leave this?

Only reason for keeping this is I might take this along to holidays, bars etc. because I wouldn't want to take my rare Glory to Rome along. Oh, and it would do a nice job of being the gateway to this "multiple use of cards" kinda game.

Now that I've found Race for the Galaxy, I have absolutely no reason to give this game a second chance; Race is a much, much better game.

RATING: 9
I like Puerto Rico, but it's not my favorite.  I bought San Juan mostly because it was rated so high, but frankly hadn't gotten it on the table because I figured it was going to be as "thick" as Puerto Rico.  Now, after a bunch of plays, I have to admit that I was very wrong.  It has many of the brilliant aspects of PR, but it's much more streamlined and fast.  It's quite easy to explain the rules and start right in.  In fact, I think I prefer SJ because of the ease of play.  This is a really good card game that feels like a full-on boardgame.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Game in a Nutshell: Card game of building a city. Choose roles to decide how to do so: Build, trade, produce, or draw.

Played as: 2,3 player

Pros: Not too hard to learn, but many things to explore when the game gets going. Really simplifies the role selection mechanic in a way the streamlines things and keeps the game moving. Scales well for any number of players. A great alternative for people who find Puerto Rico too long and too open.

Cons: At two players (or more as far as that goes) it probably lacks the optimal amount of player interaction for a face to face game (but is entertaining none the less, and others might enjoy it for this same reason). Might play slow at first while players have to read through exactly what they have in their hands. Currently, I'm fighting the idea that there's a few cards that can be a little strong when built early in the game.

Other: I played this after the similarly mechanized Race for the Galaxy and found this by far and away the easier to start out on. Definitely the way to go for people that think Puerto Rico is too complicated, takes long, and requires too much work.

Best Use: A step up from your simpler, super-fast, filler card games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Excellent game. Some similarities to Puerto Rico, but significantly different to warrant purchase.

Main advantage over Puerto Rico is the removal of 'fiddly bits' (colonists, goods etc). Also, San Juan has a greater 'luck of the draw' component - making it more accessible for new players and more dynamic in gameplay (ie. each game is different based on the cards you get).

Great way to introduce new gamers to some of the Puerto Rico mechanics (role selection, governor, trading etc) as well as a great game in its own right.

Recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Several plays against computer AI as well a couple face to face plays.  Plays similar to PR but different.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[microbadge=1714]  [microbadge=21390]

[u]08-Feb-2013[/u]:  This is the card game based on the full board game of Puerto Rico.  It uses a similar mechanism of role section, with the person choosing the role getting a bonus, to play cards into your personal tableau.  This represents the town of San Juan and all of the buildings you have constructed.  Some are production buildings so you can make goods and sell them.  Others offer additional actions, bonuses, or VP based on the role chosen.  The cards represent everything in this game - buildings, money, and goods.

It's a fantastic, lighter card game with that Euro boardgame feel.  If you've tried Race for the Galaxy and either didn't "get it" or can't find an opponent, you should give this a try.  I think it's more accessible to the family gamer, and offers plenty of strategy and tactics for all to enjoy.  Plus, I think the SoloPlay variant is great for anyone interested in a solitaire version of this one.

[u]24-Jan-2014[/u]:  This has become a solitaire staple in my collection over the past year.  Sure I like the multiplayer game, but my family hasn't really been that into it.  Bummer.  As I think it's a really solid Euro card game and would recommend to most gamers.

As a solo game using the SoloPlay rules, I have a ton of fun with it.  I really like how the additional rules and building powers mesh together to make an enjoyable and challenging point-attack style solo game experience.  I was never really a Patience/Klondike solitaire gamer.  But if I were, this would easily replace that as it plays just a quickly but offers so much more in terms of decisions and ways to score VP.  Love it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

I also like that the cards themselves are used as THE commodity.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
All plays with expansion

*Dec 2013* After 5 plays with 2-3p, I think this game is an excellent strategy filler. It plays in 30+ minutes, setup is virtually nonexistent (other than shuffling the huge deck of cards), the amount of buildings within are not overwhelming, even with expansion, and the 12 building limit forces you to choose which buildings to go for. There is some luck but going with it and not fighting it will help you proceed to victory. 

Rating reflects it as compared to all games for what it does, pros and cons. As a thinking-man's filler, I'd probably boost it up a point to 8.5. Rating could go down if replayability is limited. 

Perfect for lunch hour gaming at work. 

*Nov 2015* Raised from a 7.5 to an 8. Again, my rating includes the expansion

*Apr 2017* Got rid of it.... For Second Edition! Still well loved by me

Tight card-based adaptation of Puerto Rico.  Definitely simpler than Race for the Galaxy -- would recommend Race for more gamer-oriented folks, but San Juan is a perfect recommendation for less gamer-centric players (and potentially a sneaky way to get someone into Puerto Rico!).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
San Juan is great, and the more I play *other* two player games, the more I appreciate this one. The multiple uses of cards makes the game much more strategic and less luck-driven, and I find that the frequencies of the different cards in the deck are right on (at least as a 2er). Plenty of paths to victory, although I am especially fond of Smithy and Guild Hall.

The only way in which San Juan comes up short is that there could be a bit more direct confrontation, compared to something like Euphrates & Tigris card game. But compares favorably to building games like Starship Catan.

...oh, and then Race for the Galaxy came out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
[size=10][u][i][b]r{Initial Thoughts}r (after 5 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* Evocative card game version of [b][GameID=3076][/b]
* Different paths to victory make for some replay value (production vs purple cards)
* Quick enough that ideal method would be a best of of "x" series
* Ideal as a two player, and with more, you may as well play [b][GameID=3076][/b]
* Good for any two player library and fans of [b][GameID=3076][/b]
* Initial rating: [b]9/10[/b]

[size=10][u][i][b]b{Further Thoughts}b (after 25 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* Still playing, but replay value gets diminished as the cards become rote
* Lion's share of plays have been two player, with no desire to introduce this to a group
* Nice as a quick go to filler, but other titles are calling
* Further rating: [b]8/10[/b]

[size=10][u][i][b]g{Advanced Thoughts}g (after 50 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* Two player gaming has largely dried up, so this is in deep hibernation
* No plans to get rid of this, but the next 50+ plays will be MUCH harder to come by
* Perfect introduction to the role selection mechanic
* Advanced rating: [b]8/10[/b]

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An enjoyable mix of strategy and luck, this game is a good introduction to (the much more complex) Puerto Rico.  This is a card game in which the primary activity is building buildings (each of which is a card) that produce goods; however, the unit of currency used to pay for the buildings is the cards themselves.  This leads to interesting strategic decisions, as you must discard (spend) building cards in order to build other buildings.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A classic game of building a city from other buildings....using cards.  Hand management is critical for success as well as a balance between diversification (well, I benefit all the time, no matter what is going on) and hyper-specialization (I always Prospect, cuz I am THE Prospector).  I only have a couple of gripes with it: 1.)  getting a good combo is 50/50 luck/knowledge so new players will never get it while experienced ones will get junk sometimes.  Knowing the big-point cards is important. 2.) A lot of the time it's easy to see fairly early that you are falling behind, which can be demotivating to players.

Overall however, it is a fun, fairly light, easy to travel with game with a refreshing setting and surprisingly aggressive playing.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Everything that Puerto Rico was, but faster and less fiddly.  A big game in a little box!

RATING: 7.5
Kártyagyáras verzió (Anno XVIII), ami már tartalmazza a kiegészítőjét is (The New Buildings & The Events).

A játék egyértelműen a Race for the Galaxy öregapja (szerencsére jóval kevesebb ikonnal), és a Puerto Rico kisöccse. Ha már ilyen képzavarral élünk, akkor a 7 Wondersnek meg a nagybátyja, a Citadellának pedig az unokatestvére (vagy valami olyasmi, elég nagy a család, nehéz így). :o)

Nagyon jó a mechanizmusa, minden kártya háromféleképpen használható fel: épületként (ha megépítjük), pénzként (ha fizetünk vele egy épületért) és áruért (amit eladhatunk később újabb kártyákért).

Rövid, pörgős, egyszerű játékmenet, a játékszabályok szinte 1-2 perc alatt felfoghatók. A szerepválasztás is kiváló.

Egyetlen bajom vele, hogy kevés a konfrontáció a játékosok között, inkább pasziánsz jellegű az egész. Igaz, a kiegészítőjében szereplő eseménykártyák már konfrontatívak, de ezt még lehetett volna csiszolni.

Szóló módra is van kiváló játékszabály, azt is érdemes kipróbálni.

Race for the Galaxy is so much more interesting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Puerto Rico-lite? Yes, sorta . . . It is hard to imagine taking the currently #1 ranked and simplifying it into a card game, but that is exactly what they did.  Please note that this is NOT a Puerto Rico expansion or dependant upon the original in any respect (including knowledge of the rules).  This is its own game.  It plays "similar" to PR, but is distinctly different (e.g., cards are buildings, goods and currency)and definitely faster.  As San Juan took an abstract game (PR) and made it even more abstract, please stay clear if you do not like euros.  Just how good is Puerto Rico?  Well, it is ranked #1 and San Juan (its offspring) is currently at #38.  How many games (game-systems) can boast two games in the Top 40?  Award(s):  Hall of Games (Austria).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After few first games, I must say I really like it.

Although I am skeptical about how often it would hit the table...

RATING: 6
Despite being a port of the Puerto Rico system to a card game it displays the Puerto Rico look and feel very well. The best thing is that it is simpler (and more accessible for newbies) and easier to set up without losing most of the depth of play that Puerto Rico has. It also plays well as a 2-player game, whereas Puerto Rico does not. I'd give this another 1-2 marks if the outcome weren't so heavily influenced by the card draw in the first two rounds of the game.Updated: Played one game with the significant other. She thought it was OK but not great. This game is OK as a light alternative to Puerto Rico, but I'd prefer to play Puerto Rico.

RATING: 7
This game is similar to Citadels, but is less cut-throat.  Unfortunately this makes it a little bland, although it's ideal for players who take games too personally.

This game takes a while to teach because there are so many different buildings so everyone needs to read all the cards during the many 'get cards/discard cards' phases.

It feels like solitaire to me in that it passes the time, with little pleasure in the actual process.

RATING: 7.5
I've so far only played this as a 2 player game and I like it quite a lot. A good blend of strategy, tactics and luck. At this point I'm not sure how good the replayability will be in the long term as there are optimal strategies based on what cards and combinations you manage to draw. At this early stage though I am not bored with the game play and still have some exploration of strategies to pursue. I can see how some would rather want to play the deeper Puerto Rico... and I can also see how some would say this suffers from the same optimization analysis problems and dryness of PR with the caveat of even more luck thrown in. I think my personal rating of SJ has an almost equal chance of dropping or rising which means this may never become a top tier game for me... but rather a solid and nicely scalable game for 2-4 that has the further advantage of playing fairly quickly which helps mitigate the bad luck of being hosed by the cards from time to time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
San Juan is a very clever adaptation of Puerto Rico, and it does a good job of capturing the feel of the original game while providing a play experience that is decidedly different. I really like the card usage mechanic, which allows every card to be used either as a building (the info on its face) or as a resource.  This really emphasizes the hand management aspects, and makes for a rewarding tactical experience.

I have only played the game with 2 players, and while it works with two, we quickly found that producing goods was a far inferior action to building something or drawing new cards.  This meant that our two-player games became nothing more than an attempt to draw the highest scoring "big" building cards.  It got to the point where we removed the library, because the first player to play it would win.  I imagine the game is better with more than two people, so I'm waiting on changing the rating until I have played with more than two.  As a two player game, it is fine, and it has the feel of Puerto Rico, but it's not great.  Good, but not great.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I've had this one around for years... judging by the layer of dust, it's been perched on the very top of the "unplayed, should try soon" stack for most of that time... I've read the rules, tried the solitaire variant... and always just put it back. No reason.

And then suddenly, with all my other games to choose from, a two-player game of San Juan - and BAM! The darned thing is just as good as the people on the Geek have been telling me! Cripes! I have a lot of catching up to do, to make up for the years I've lost...

My current favourite. What an idiot I've been.

RATING: 7.5
Overall comment: the card game of Puerto Rico which plays a little like the board game but really is a game unto itself. It plays quick and has many light decisions to make. The game is good for new players.

Ratings:
Initial(wow factor): 7 (card game with alot of tans and blacks)
Family: 7 (wife does not like it, kids request it)
Game group: N/A (has not been played)
AP: 10 (there is no slow down in this game)
Solo play: 10 (#1 solo - I am addicted to the SoloPlay game and this has caused the rating to go up - 7 without the solo play.  Many paths to victory and the pressure on using the roles properly)

Purchased: 2006
Luck factor (1-10high): 5 (cards are earned but you have to decide which ones to keep and how to use them)
Recommend expansions: N/A
Age range: 8+

Reason purchased: liked Puerto Rico, Geek analysis, looking for a way to get family interested in the Puerto Rico mechanics

Pros: the game plays quick and you can affect the other player a little bit. Once you know how to use the buildings you can see how they can affect your chances.  SoloPlay saves the game and creates my enthusiasm for it.
Cons: the regular game is a little dull after a number of plays. There is not much to look at and the regular game plays the same everytime.

Recommendation: This is a card game with a board game mentality so card players do struggle a little with the choices. You can play this game in about 40 minutes and it a satisfying game. Seek out the SoloPlay game to bring out the fun factor.
Replay rating: regular moderate (SoloPlay High)
Game value(plays/game cost ratio): Very high - once again SoloPlay but above average for the normal play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A resource management game that is very quick to learn and that scales well to two or more players.  I like the nice balance between building (12 buildings ends the game) and the need for production (buildings cost cards that are replenished via production).  Finally, the flow of a turn strikes me as very engaging.  There is no sitting back and watching the other player make moves for 5 - 10 minutes, and a turn is split into three sub-phases that involve each player.  Might go up in rating with more plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Over fifty plays on BSW, mostly quick 2p games. Very rewarding when played in that fashion. (BSW only)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Similar mechanics to Puerto Rico, but played competely with cards. It finishes quickly in under an hour, it is a well thought out game with all the buildings and is a good follow up to the orgiginal. There is a luck factor in drawing the right cards (guild hall, city hall) to win. This game always leaves me wanting to play another hand. There are various strategies to consider, such as the guild hall strategy, but this could be be beaten by a pure purple strategy and city hall, but you need to get the right cards. With 2 players, remove the libraries from the game, as I have seen the designer say somewhere they are quite powerful in a 2 player game. Also in a 2 player game, it is almost possible to try any strategy since you will likely get a chance at any card in the deck.

RATING: 5
Excitement of playing PR card game faded rather quickly. Played 33 times and no desire to play it again. There are 2 fundamental problems about SJ.

1. No dilemma about choosing roles as there are no coins on it. Same roles are chosen again and again...
2. Too many diffent cards with variety of usefulness. Unlike PR, buildings are not available to anyone. Thus it has quite a huge luck of draw.

It maybe suitable to play SJ if everyone already knows PR and wants to play something light with the seemingly similar flavor. Otherewise there are tons of better games in the same weight.

RATING: 7
San Juan is the antithesis of St Petersburg, the former is a board game that looks like a card game, the latter a board game that masks as a board game. It works fine (a good two player game), but it's too short for any serious strategies. I'm not completely sold on this game, as the game feels like breaking an egg and trying to hold the white and the yolk in your hand, often it ends too soon, not in a positive way.*update* My rating is going down. There is just too much randomness in the draws, and the game is too short to rectify these drawbacks with the infusion of strategy (and this comes from someone who sees a strategical element in Both Schotten Totten and Category 5)

RATING: 7
First of all, do not expect this to be Puerto Rico in card format.  There are many more differences than there are similarities.  

I do like this game, but I just wished that they would have pasted on a better theme.  Puerto Rico can get away with a dry theme because the game play is fantastic.  

I do like how accessible San Juan is.  As busy as I am I like playing games that are quick to set-up, play in under 90 minutes, and makes you make thought provoking choices.  San Juan certainly accomplishes this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Hmmmm . . . after several games, I'm still not sure what I think of this game.  I think it's an interesting adaptation of PR, but or course, it lacks much of the strategy and tactics.

This is a great game for those who like to build things, as that's really all you do - collect cards and build.

There seem to be many possible strategies in this game, but some (i.e. jack rabbit, or violet builder, or producer with black market and crane) seem to be the only really viable options.  There is a little to learn about cards that work well with others, but once a player picks a strategy, the choices become somewhat obvious.

I think my ambivalence (please look this word up in the dictionary if you think it's a negative comment :-) comes from the feel that there might be more to this game, but there doesn't seem to be.

A good variation might be some way to see future cards that you might access every three rounds or so.  This might force players to "plan" more.  A building excluding other options or some other way to create scarcity in the game might also generate a need to plan, and plan correctly, from the start.

If I just give up and approach this game as a light building game, then I am usually satisfied with its play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my first euros, and so I may have a favorable bias that makes me like this title and dislike Race for the Galaxy. There is a bit of luck involved -- you want to draw as many of a certain set of bonusing cards at the right time, mid- to late- game -- but by the same token you can make your luck by building an engine that lets you do so. There are multiple ways to build such an engine, and thus multiple winning tactics, although there may only be one winning strategy (to build an economic production engine and then bonusing buildings). It is a card game, plays kind of like a conventional card game, but I'd rather play it than even my favorite conventional card games (Oh Hell, Pinochle, etc).

[color=#117bc0][b]Probably rather play:[/b][/color] Tichu

That keeps my rating lower.  Having played Race for the Galaxy, I do not see myself ever playing this one again.

Why this is not a 10:
-> I do not want to play this all the time; I've played this a lot on the computer and am ready to see a different game.
-> I prefer direct confrontation a little more.
-> I prefer RftG's theme and depth much more.

RATING: 6.5
A card game version of Puerto Rico. It preserves the general feel of PR, particularly the role selection intricacies and theme, and in a shorter package to boot.

However, it is considerably more one-dimensional. The lack of shipping is noticeable, and it is much harder to block opponents from trades.

All in all, while still a good game, I think I'd prefer either PR or Race for the Galaxy in any situation.

RATING: 9
(I also own expansion from "Alea/Rio Grande Chest")

First I thought making game simpler and adding element of luck into Puerto Rico would make game worse. San Juan shows it's not the case. Works well with 2-4 players.

Update (5.1.2007): I'm starting to like San Juan more and more. Rating adjusted from 8 to 9.

Although Race for the Galaxy has a bit more of everything compared to San Juan I still like SJ better. Cards are more varied in RftG but they are a bit (too) complex and it's quite easy to forget an icon or two while playing. Especially for a new (or old who haven't played in a while) player. Only thing I absolutely like more in RftG is the phase selection as then every round doesn't necessarely have everything. In San Juan with 4 players there is no such surprise element what comes to role selection. Therefore I like the game best with 2 or 3 players. Might try a home rule someday with RftG-style role selection (probably needs a small tuning with some roles).

RATING: 10
San Juan is my favorite Euro.  This simple, quick-playing game has seen more playings in our home than all other Euros put together.

Components are very nice.  Rules are simple and clear.  The game system is very good.  You are only supposed to play this with 2-4, but we play this with 5 all the time and the game system is so robust that it can handle it with no problem.  Playability and enjoyment are extremely high.  Realism?  Well, it's a Euro.

Get it.  Play it.  Enjoy it.

RATING: 7.5
If this game existed by itself, I would probably rate it a nine.  But we learned Puerto Rico first (I rate PR a 10) and I can't help comparing them in my head while playing.  This fairly deep game can seem a little shallow when compared with Puerto Rico and seems easier to always pick one strategy and go with it.  That said, the multiple uses of the cards is genius and the game is fast and portable.  My wife likes this better than Puerto Rico because it's much faster.

Edit:  I played only two or three games on BSW, but they helped open my eyes to new strategies.  They spread among my little group and increased our fun level.  This is getting a deserved 9 now.

Edit: Luck factor among evenly skilled players has moved this back down to an 8 and then a 7.5.  Great game, but a palace really can make all the difference. Plus, it just doesn't have the variety of my most favorite games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is an awesome game.  Sure it gets a few plays because it's portable, fast to play, fast to setup, fun, scales well from 2-4...wait what was I trying to say here?

My mom even likes this game!  It can be played aggressively, but still in a way where people have fun.  You can play terribly and still be at least a little satisfied with your city. :)

After playing well over 50 games I can find criticism in the big buildings overshadowing the rest of your city- you really need find and build at least some of them, but that's part of the game.  This is NOT multiplayer solitaire.  Watching and annoying others is key to success.

The only thing that could make this better would be an expansion that allowed another couple players and added some further variety (especially to the 6 cost buildings).

One of my favorites.  Check it out.

RATING: N/A

1. Treasure Chest
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
50+ plays. A brilliant adaption of the Puerto Rico system to a card playing environment. The game is all about finding combinations of cards that work well together, securing you a source of income (to buy further cards) and allowing you to get VP's more cheaply. The mechanic of cards being either a building or money, but not both, is fundamental to the constant tension the game produces. Each turn you're faced with the dilemma of looking for better cards, or which card in the hand do you wish to convert into a building, but can you afford to give up the other potential buildings in your hand and use them as money. The game has been somewhat superceded by Race For The Galaxy which uses a similar system but has been made "bigger" in complexity, but the simplicity of SJ still ensures it has a place in the rotation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Played a few times.  Complete and in great shape.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
"A genius design of a card game. It captured the essence of Puerto Rico, while eliminating the annoying parts (difficulty of selling; being forced to ship). I much prefer SJ over the bloated Race for the Galaxy. However, as much as I respect SJ, I don't enjoy leaching games that much, so I don't love SJ."

What I like:
- Amazing and ground-breaking mechanisms
- Multiple paths to victory
- Quick; simple rules

What I don't like:
- Has more leaching than I prefer
- I wish it had RftG-like icons to show which role activates the card
- The 2p variant (1.5 roles per round) is merely OK

I think the weight of 2.3 is reasonable. There is complexity with the building special abilities, and confusion with the multiple uses of cards. But overall it's on the lighter/simpler side, so accessible to people who have already mastered a gateway game.

Traded it away (for a small grail game)...now I want it back.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
プエルトリコの簡易版として扱われるのはあまりに勿体無い。
カードを種類分けする必要が無く、金・生産物・建築物・手札といった区分けをカードの使い方だけで表現しているのが凄い。
プエルトリコシステムで、他者へ得させまいとする絡みが生じる。
ルールは割と簡単で、勝ち筋は複数。
カードの質が良く、スリーブ要らず

コスト6カードの得点計算が若干面倒
スコアカードと鉛筆は不要なので、その分省スペースでもっと安価にして欲しかった（決して高価では無いけど）
鉱脈の4枚コスト違いが自己申告制なのが残念。オープンして確認させるルールだと駄目だったのかな？
変動相場のおまけ感が強い。
