=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A satisfying card game which happens to be perfect with three players, and also good with two and four.  I love card games like this. Play it in a bar, while traveling, take it to your neighbor, play it before bed with your sweetie.  I like it way better than both its siblings Puerto Rico and Race for the Galaxy.

There are many possible strategies to San Juan, most determined by your starting hand or the cards you draw in the first couple rounds.  The wins in our group have been pleasingly varied in terms of strategy.  

Multi-player solitaire? Sort of. There is interaction, but it is subtle and hard to see at first.  Torquing that interaction in your favor is the key. You need to set it up so that you are [i]in phase[/i] and knock your opponent(s) [i]out of phase[/i].

San Juan is less satisfying with 4. It took me a while to see just why 4 players threw it off - it has to do with the fact that in every round, four of the five possible roles will be chosen. This makes the game less interactive and more predictable. With two or three players, only three out of the five roles will be chosen.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Race for the Galaxy Light.  Would like to buy it because my wife enjoys it.

RATING: 7

One flaw is that a lot of the buildings are underpowered and never see play.  And the Guild Hall is way overpowered.

RATING: 8

San Juan has its own options as well, as one can employ about two strategies: heavy on production or heavy on purple buildings. It misses out, of course, some of Puerto Rico's options, but it's still a quick, light-strategy game.

My wife does not like Race for the Galaxy much, but likes San Juan so I play this once in a while with her. Personally I prefer Race for the Galaxy, as there is more choices to be made, more ways to score points and so on...

Oh...and of course role selection system is very similar to the one in Puerto Rico.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Definitely overrated game. A nice game of building, with an enourmous weight of luck and very small (if any) interaction. The small number of roles and the limited power of some of them makes the interaction low even during the phase of choosing the role. It's not the only problem during that phase: it always seems that you can either choose one certain role, otherwise get the miner and a card. No other choice. And every time you get a role, every player will be about at the same level of buildings, resources and money, as soon as with so few roles it will always happen that everyone will build, produce and sell in the same round, unless his position is dramatic. The order of these actions being important exactly in the same manner for all the players.
Pros are that it's length is correct and after all it's easy and light. It would be a 7 if only every single building wasn't written in german. A problem that in PR can be fixed, here, with cards, is much more difficult, and you pass the whole game reading the rules until you don't know them all by heart (maybe after 4-5 matches). The idea of using the cards for multiple functions is great, but then, why create different (and costly) pieces for the prices and for the roles? This game could all be done with a single deck of cards, making it much cheaper.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a very good game! It's fast, it's good with 2, 3 or 4 and it has a good mix between strategy and depth, and the luck of the cards. Every game is different and there's a lot to learn in selecting the best path to win with the cards you get. That's why I always lose when I play on BSW! I think I actually prefer it to its older brother... or maybe not!
[UPDATE]: This is even better than the previous statement implies. I've been playing it a lot lately and been having a lot of fun! Upgraded the rating (8->9).

[UPDATE]: Downgraded it from 9 to a 7. Race for the galaxy is the sole responsible for this simply because I don't think I'll ever suggest San Juan again. It's still a good game and I don't mind playing it if suggested. But given the choice I'll prefer Race for the galaxy everytime!

RATING: 6
Nice adaption of Puerto Rico. I prefer RftG when playing with people familiar with that game. With new players, San Juan often proves more fun simply because it's easier for them to grasp the game and play competitively. San Juan, more than RftG, seems to suffer from lucky draws of the 6-cost buildings swinging the game. 

The cards in the Alea Treasure Chest expansion are recommended. They do the same thing as the RftG expansions - that is, open up new strategies without increasing the complexity of the game. Great!

RATING: 8

I even discovered new good combos, so my new verdict is that this is a game that doesn't grow stale over time.  Many games have come into our repertoire since, but this is still a truly great game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Wonderful Filler+ card game. The manager of the local game store told me that the only flaw in this game was that I wouldn't enjoy it as much after I started playing its big brother (Puerto Rico).  But, I'm happy to report that it simply isn't true. Not only does this give a lot of the buzz of a full game of Puerto Rico, it stands on its own because the (deck / tableau / hand / trick / whatever you want to call it) aspect of the game that comes from the cards is fantastic. The engine aspect is exciting, it plays smooth as butter, and because the length of the game is determined by the number of buildings which are visible to both players - the tension mounts as the game advances and the abilities of the players increase. Such a good game. Really. Fantastic. I keep hearing that Silver Mines & the Library are overpowered, but I don't think it's true. Coffee is a great production card, and combined with an Aqueduct and a Trading Post, you get production and trading bumps on everyone's turn - not just your own turn as with the library. You'll buy what you want at full price and still be swimming in money cards... you'll find that you need a Harbor and/or Chapel just so you don't wind up hand-limited every turn. Great game - wouldn't change a thing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Though there are interesting card effect combinations and role/card selection sequencing to consider, players' displays are overwhelming, making player's status difficult to assess and hence I get no competitive tension. Almost typically now, resolution of the winner is a long winded maths effort, which I find dull and makes the experience anticlimatic.

CONs:

RATING: 4
A good way to kill time but the guild hall is a gamewrecker. 

It only works well for four players, and i'd bump it to a 6 for three or four players, but as a two player game i'd give this game a zero. Total luck based on whether you see a guild hall or not.  So call it a 4 overall.

It has the usual Euro component feel, but man it's all a waste except for the cards and trade tiles. The rest is "nice" (the role tiles) or totally a waste (pencil and score pad - you can't count to 20-30 in your head???). Basically, I felt like I paid $23 for a single deck of cards.

RATING: 7.7
Kártyás játék némi kieggel, így belekerültek plusz kártyák, amikkel lehet drágább épületeket építeni, valamint ezzel 6 személlyel is lehet játszani. 

Negatívumok: Bosszantóan hosszú volt 6 játékossal (3 óra magyarázattal együtt, bár az alig volt 15-20 perc), amit biztos lehetne rövidíteni, de nem hiszem, hogy 2 óránál gyorsabban be lehetne fejezni! 
Nem árt ismerni a kártyákat, mire érdemes befektetni, mire nem.
Pozitívumok: Izgalmas végig a játék és folyamatos fejtörést okoz, hogy mi legyen a következő telepítendő lap. Az első helyemhez az kellett, hogy már az elején leraktam egy kápolnát, amire minden forduló végén tettem egy lapot, ami a végén 11 pontot jelentett. Illetve vettem egy céhet, ami ugyan hatba kerül, de minden telepített olyan lapért, ami árut ad a végén 2gyp-t ad darabonként.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Though it uses the terminology from Puerto Rico, the game feels more like a variant of Citadels - select characters and build. As such San Juan is far more random than PR. Card-flow exceeds that of most other card games. The buildings/cards appear to be a bit unbalanced as some are very strong, delivering a lot of points, and others with similar costs, are significantly weaker - get the right card early on and you are unbeatable. Being an Alea game I would have expected serious decision trees...nope, this is a very lite, luck-ridden game with limited choices. For serious play try Battleline, Blue Moon or Roma. Over-hyped, as this is an average game that would have had average ratings if it was not PR themed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Many (many) plays prior to June 2011.

RATING: 8
[floatleft][ImageID=117026][/floatleft]Many people say that [thing=28143][/thing] surpasses San Juan. I don't agree with that; San Juan stands on its own. Both games share a number of similarities. I can see why it is so easy to compare the two games but to discount San Juan because of the existence of RftG is ludicrous. I will concede the fact that both games fill the same niche in a game collection and having both games is moderately redundant. It really comes down to personal preference and my preference is San Juan.

The [thing=40688][/thing] does a superb job at expanding this game.

RATING: 8
I can't think of a better board game to card game adaptation.  San Juan manages to retain the flavor of Puerto Rico, while still being an interesting game in its own right.  There is certainly a fair degree of luck, but the more skillful player will usually win.  One drawback (for new players, at least), is that you really need to know the deck in order to play well.

RATING: 9
Very similar in feel to Race for the Galaxy.  However, this game is *much* easier to learn for new players.  The strategies are more immediately evident, and there's much less to figure out for each individual card.  In Race, you've got to simultaneously learn all the icons and figure how good the cards are.  With this game, its much more straightforward and each card really only does one thing.

RATING: 7
A very well done adaption of Puerto Rico. You can see its heritage, it captures many of the ideas of PR. 
I prefer it to Puerto Rico.
Very much liked how it used cards as both money, actions you may be able to take, trade goods... 
Like how the randomness of the cards will interfere with your plans. 
The highlight of both games is how the taking the bonus and action of the roles supply the victory difference. 
Playes well with 2 or 3 users - with 4 I'd rather go all in on Puerto Rico.

RATING: 5.5
Good little managing game where you have to try to predict your oponents moves in order to take advantage of them. Some of the buildings seems to be very powerfull and can shift the game toward on player if you can place them early in the game. I prefere Race for the Galaxy or Glory to Rome in the same type of game, but San Juan is more appealing to my girlfriend than the two others witch is a big point in his favor.

San Juan est un bon jeu de management ou vous devez tenter de prédir les actions de vos adversaires afin de vous en servir à votre profit. Certains bâtiments sont très puissants et peuvent faire basculer la partie rapidement pour un joueur si vous les placez tôt dans la partie. Je préfère Race for the Galaxy ou Glory to Rome, mais ma conjointe préfère San Juan ce qui est un bon point en sa faveur.

RATING: 6

Also, major concern here is that two of the buildings are mandatory for victory (without expansion of course). If your opponent has 1+ of them and you don't, goodbye victory. If all opponents know this, it becomes a race towards optimisation, but it circles around quickly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
= 2014-07-11

I've since played San Juan again and I'd like to revise my statements. I like the game. It's fun, it's quick and it's tense.

= 2014-05-22

This isn't saying much, but I like this game SOOOOO much better than RftG. My singlular attempt at RftG stands as quite possibly the most frustrating and unfun experience I have ever had playing a game. San Juan, on the other hand, kept things simple and exposed the core of what this style of game is about. RftG feels like someone played two hours of Calvinball and then took a snapshot of all the random rules he'd come up with by that point. San Juan is more like a casual game of soccer with friends. While I've promised FW I would give RftG at least one more shot before passing final judgement, I'm pretty sure, after playing San Juan, that it won't change my mind. Why? Because I'm not sure I liked San Juan all that much either.

I'm a software developer. I chose to get an MS in Electrical Engineering not because I care about things EE's *do* all that much, but because I liked the science and math behind it. I like the puzzles and the meaningful brain teasers. I've come home from work elated at a particularly mind bending problem I worked through and have cheered myself on as each new function in a piece of code managed to successfully handle yet another special case. I do this for my job now and maybe that has affected the games I prefer. Rather than picking up the latest Feld or Martin Wallace game and hacking through the myriad of Byzantine minigames pieced together to obstruct the puzzle underneath, I'd rather chuck some dice, flick some discs, or rap my knuckles on the table and declare "Gin" while drinking the same. If I wanted to optimize a points engine, I'd go back to the office.

I don't really know where San Juan fits in this. It wasn't a fun enough puzzle to solve and it wasn't a light enough activity for passing the time. I'm pretty sure I'll play it again and I'll keep my promise to try RftG again, but I don't think I'm going to end up liking either one.

Now if I could just get someone to play Glory to Rome with me...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Unbalanced costs for cards, just like Puerto Rico, but it does a good job of translating the original into a more streamlined card game version. Removing the clutter and extra layer of the colonists (and shipping to a lesser extent) was a masterstroke - it keeps the majority of the strategy of PR intact, while making the game quicker. I prefer this to PR, since if I'm going to be playing a unbalanced (yet interesting) game, I'd rather do it in half the time yet still retain most of the feel.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Good and quick cardgame. Played with my girlfriend, she liked it. YES!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I have only played this 2p, but it is very fun. It captures the feel of Puerto Rico with a lot less hassle. It plays fast, and the three ways the cards are used is an exquisite mechanism. You really have to know which cards can give you the most benefit, and which cards you can give up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Plays much more quickly than Puerto Rico, with less set-up and fiddling with small parts, yet provides many of the same sorts of interactions.  One major difference, and significant flaw of San Juan: in Puerto Rico you can build any building you choose that is still available, usually over 6 good choices, but in San Juan you're stuck with whatever you happened to draw, and that almost never gives you as many as 3 sensible buildings to choose from, and it's often 0, just by bad luck.  This can wreck your whole game if you aren't dealt the most useful cards in the first few rounds. Still, in all, a fun game. Variant: deal 8 cards, discard down to 4, when starting, this reduces bad luck in the opening and changes it to player decision, and makes it a better game.  The more I play San Juan, the more I like it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Decent game, could take it or leave it.

Great building card game.
Gets lots of play.

RATING: 7
This is a game I did not expect to like but did.  I find I enjoy card games and since this game incorporated pulling from a deck of cards and "Lady Luck" along with skill it was very stimulating for me.  This is not a fast game but not a long game either.  Maybe 40 min to hour and a half. There were many ways to gather points in this game.  Resources, buildings, or simply getting a card that allows you extra points. The decisions you make very much effect the outcome but luck easily can come in and mess you up as well.  This game kept you hopping each turn.  It was very competitive with no cooperative mechanics at all.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]RO:[/b] [i]03/07/2016[/i]

Oh geeze, I've played San Juan 53 times as of this writing and all I had to say about it up to that point was: 

"[i]Interesting card game; build buildings to get resources to produce more buildings. Get victory points and outmaneuver your opponent(s) to win. This is our most played game, but probably not our favorite anymore.[/i]"

The first couple sentences can describe basically [i][b]every hobby card game ever made[/i][/b]. So what is so special about San Juan that I've played it more than virtually any other game in my collection? Well, it helps that it was one of the first. It's easy to understand but incredibly satisfying to play, plus, skill is a major factor, or at least familiarity. When we bring this out with new people, I don't play the first couple games. I teach and answer questions because if I play I will win handily. It's not as luckless as Puerto Rico but once you understand how the game works luck isn't a major factor in the design anymore. 

San Juan recently received a reprint with new content, I would heartily advise anyone who enjoys card games to pick this one up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I've played a few hundred games of this (most of those against AI), and it's become fairly automatic to me.  You either get the right cards or you don't.  If one player gets the good violet cards to open with, he's just going to do better.  Additionally you _need_ to draw the big buildings to win, if you don't find any, you cannot win.  

Despite the flaws, it's still a fun game, but I find it too random and that there is only one victory path in 2 players.  (In 4 players producing is slightly more feasible... if somebody else is doing it with you).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.3
I've only had it for a couple of weeks, but I'm really enjoying it.  I've played mostly 2-person games with my son or wife or a friend.  I've also played a bunch with the computer version.  Don't know all the nuances yet of course.

Update: Now we've had the game for a couple of months and it's becoming one of our top two or three most played games (along with Carcassonne and Carcassonne-The City).  It's a really cool game once you get used to what all the cards do.  A neat feature is that you end up using different strategies based on what types of cards you get early on.  So the game feels different on different days.

Also, I'd highly recommend it as a game for couples looking for a low-confrontational game.  While there are times when you choose to do something that wouldn't help your opponent, for the most part you're concentrating on creating your own city.

Update(Feb. '09): Not playing too much anymore.  Wife and I prefer Agricola, Crokinole, Zooleretto, or Battleline instead.  But I'm sure it's still a great, great game.  And we'll bring it on trips b/c of its size.

Update (July '10): Wife and I are playing it quite a bit on a trip to Bermuda. I just moved it up to #9 on my Top 10. It's that good.  Sure there's some luck in the card draw, but that's cool. And lots of different strategies for each time you play.

Update (May '11): Knocked it back down to an 8.8 b/c in the last month I've learned to love Race for the Galaxy.

RATING: 7
Mostly I play the Mac version of this game by "Jim" and routinely get my arse kicked. I love it. For me this is PR without the complicated rules, fiddly game play and little more infusion of luck...but not too much. I think it's easier to teach than either PR or Race for the Galaxy.

Why not an 8 or a 9? I think there's some balance issues in the game. Some of 6 cost purple buildings will wildly swing a game towards the end while others are almost worthless without combinations of other purple buildings. I think with some more 4 and 5 cost purple buildings that grant abilities instead of just VPs (i.e. more like the library), this game would be nearly perfect.

I'd much rather play Puerto Rico, so this doesn't get much play time, other than as a two player game.  And frankly, it is much better with three or four, IMHO.

Edit 11/07: I've actually played quite a few two player games now and appreciate it more as such.  It feels like it has more cards than are useful.  Many of the cards feel like University in PR - nice idea, but no really that useful relatively.  It seems like it too frequently comes down to Guild Hall or City Hall, though I think that shows a lack of experience in the game more than a deficiency of the game.  Need to play more to fairly assess (I've only played ~30 games, far more than I've recorded since I started recording plays late in the game, so to speak).

RATING: 4
Guildhall is too good.  The card draws are too random in general -- most cards are balanced on average, but in any given context there is huge variance in value between things you could draw, which is just as random as having some always be better than others.  The randomized market is fiddly without adding depth.  Strong first turn advantage with no mitigation.  Hard to catch up from behind.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
13-07-2014. Rated after 3 plays. Puerto Rico: Cardgame. Game in which you draft actions and build buildings to gather resources to buy new and better buildings. Resources are sold for money, reflected by cards. You discard cards to place one of the cards as buildings, that give you special abilities (and few VPs) or just VPs. Endgame is triggered by whomever builds their 12th building. Winner whomever has most VPs. 

I love games like this and regret not finding it earlier. Artwork and design is somewhat drab and the box is too big but the game is lovely. RFTG is now firmly on my want to play list, as I'd like the the theme and art better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Van Robert

RATING: 8
Good, fast game - 20 minutes with 3 players, 30 minutes with 4.  It can be a bit too dependent on whether a player gets the right 6-cost card to go with what they've already built up, and it can feel unlucky if you never happen to ever draw any 6-cost cards, but it's so short, you can just play again and hope for better luck. I prefer it over Race for the Galaxy - not as deep, but allows for a lot more table talk and just a more enjoyable time playing together.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.7
San Juan is probably more fun than Puerto Rico, but its not half the game. If I was asked to play one it would be San Juan, but I wouldn't pick either if it was my choice. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I really enjoy this game. It's quick to play and I feel it can be played very competitively between players who know it well. There are multiple strategies one can use to play the game that gives it more replay value in my book. Sure, much can be said for the luck of the draw, but each player draws so many cards over the course of the game that you're likely to see every building at least once, it may just not come when you want it. But there are multiple card combinations you can use to be competitive in the game even if your favorite cards don't show up when you want them. I feel this game gets better with more plays as you're able to understand the relationships between the cards better. You can play this game with as much player interaction as you like. Personnaly, I like to really pay attention to my opponent's capabilities and actions. You can strongl influence someone's likely actions by the roles you play and the buildings you construct.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Solid little game I got at a yard sale.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A good amount of depth for a card game. It could be considered multiplayer solitare, as there is no direct interaction between players. Plenty of interesting decisions and variability between games. The resources to build buildings are the actual building cards themselves, couple that with the unpredictability of chosen roles, and you have yourself a tense and satisfying game. Building decisions can be especially excruciating. If this is Puerto Rico lite, then I look forward to giving its counterpart a try. I continue to remain impressed with the alea medium box series.

RATING: 9
Respect a KártyaGyárnak ill. annak aki elkészítette az elektronikus változatot a nyomtatáshoz.
---
Nagyon szuperül működő, letisztult játékmenet. Ideális akár már 2 fővel is. Klasszikus "kéz menedzsment", számtalan út vezethet a győzelemhez.
Az eredeti árát tekintve kicsit húzós az érte kért összeg, de még azzal is ajánlott darab. (Meg is venném eredetiben, ha lenne magyar kiadása...)
A design az amin még lehetne egy kicsit fejleszteni, hogy még ütősebbé váljon a játék.
Kis helyen elfér, viszonylag kicsi a játék közbeni helyigénye, egy szó, mint száz, bármikor jöhet belőle egy parti! ;)
---
Frissítés: Azt kell mondjam, hogy 2 fő feletti játékos szám  esetén kicsit megborul a játék. Túlságosan megnő a szerencse szerepe. Ha nem jön jó lap, akkor az ember a többiek szerepválasztásának a foglya lesz, és sodródik az árral. Aztán egyszer csak azt veszi észre, hogy behozhatatlan hátrányba került. (Ezen a ponton hiányolom belőle a konfrontatív jelleget, hogy rendesen keresztbe lehessen tenni a többieknek).
Könnyedebb játéknak továbbra is kiváló a gyorsasága miatt, és nagy előnye, hogy kevésbé hardcore játékosoknak is könnyen tanítható.
---
No rájöttem, hogy a legutóbbi frissítés igazán csak abban az esetben igaz, ha stratégákkal kártyázunk. Családi szinten azért önmagában is megállja a helyét.

RATING: 6
You have to play this a couple times to get a proper sense of it, so don't give up after just one try if you don't like it. When everyone playing is competent, the scores tend to be very close, which is great. With four players, this game is at its very best, because there is more incentive to try a production strategy. With four players, I rate this game an  [bgcolor=#66FF99][s][color=#66FF99]-[/color][/s][b]8[/b][s][color=#66FF99]-[/color][/s][/bgcolor]  . San Juan is a great step along the way to Race for the Galaxy.

UPDATE: Around 90+ plays (which is awesome), we started to cool on San Juan. Because it got so there was only a couple ways to win. Normally, I eschew expansions. But we gave the New Buildings expansion a try. It rules, and breathes new life into San Juan :)

RATING: 6
It's kinda like 7 Wonders. There's this feeling of creating something because you can see cards accumulating before you, but it's very hard to imagine what's happening, there's just not enough to go on and some mechanics and building abilities even get in the way. San Juan doesn't even try to have direct interaction, whereas 7 Wonders fakes it. In spite of that, I think I like this better than 7 wonders, because it goes over quicker while really giving a very comparable experience. More isn't always better you know. It's short, cute, goes down real easy, but it ain't too sweet. It's rather bland.

We've only played two-player, but there's always something I want to grab more for more than two. We've also given several other two-player titles a try and they've all only added to my feelings about San Juan.

RATING: 8
I originally liked this less that Puerto Rico, now I prefer San Juan. I originally liked Race for the Galaxy better, now I prefer San Juan. I guess it's about time to give this little game its due, hm? 

This is a card game that deserves just about all of the accolades it has gotten. It play fast and light, but with some genuine strategy. I do wish the game had more interaction, and you can basically play on auto-pilot after a few games of it. But it's laid-back, thoughtful, and inexpensive. I think this is one of those card games all gamers should pick up.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Having played a lot of MtG, I find it difficult to enjoy card games unless they are fairly heavy. I'm glad I persisted with San Juan, because now I love it and am keen to check out Puerto Rico.

The cards in San Juan are like a mixture of three or four simple Magic decks: you see which algorithm your hand leans towards and play that style out. The lack of optimisation is balanced out a bit by good knowledge of your opponents' cards (type and distribution). As a two-player game, this is non-confrontational enough to replace Lost Cities for us, and as a 3 or 4P game it's got more interaction and fun.

Three players seems to be the sweet spot, as there's less certainty about which roles will be chosen. Actually, if it were up to me I would only play this with three people. 4P seems a bit preprogrammed, and 2P is multiplayer solitaire.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In San Juan players are racing to achieve fame and fortune by building up the city of San Juan.  The winner is decided when one player finishes building his 12th building.  The player at the end of the game with the most victory points wins.  Each round 5 actions are made available through the use of role placards; each role grants the same action to all players, and grants an additional privilege to the role owner.  Each turn players must decide which action they want to take; however, once a role has been chosen it is unavailable until the next round.  The actions vary from drawing cards, building, producing goods, and selling goods (which grant you more cards).  The cards in San Juan function as three things, the building printed on the card, currency (used to build the building), or a good; this simple fact causes players to carefully weigh which buildings they want to construct, and which ones they are going to use as either goods or currency.

The game plays quickly and despite the simplicity of the rules there are some key decisions to make throughout the game.  Choosing the right role at the right time, to either leverage the privilege or deny that privilege to other players, is the main player interaction mechanic, and the fulcrum of your strategy; however, since the cards you draw are random players will need to continually evaluate their strategy and adapt it based on their current circumstances.  Beyond choosing which role to assume on your turn, players must carefully consider how to best use each card in their hand, as some cards must be spent (discarded) in order to win the game.

San Juan is not a deep thinking strategy game, instead it is a fast light-medium to medium strategy card game rewarding careful decisions and adaptability.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Easy to learn and quick to play. There's a fair chunk of luck in cards picked up, but you can make your own luck by picking up the Councillor and choosing the best of five. (Of course if another player has the Prefecture  or library you're screwed.) There's still some of the Puerto Rico feel in choosing the actions, and it does play much faster. I like it for what it is. Found it getting better after a few plays. Found it getting old after a few more. Still, I can appreciate that it's a good game, even if I am a bit tired of it.

UPDATE: New edition with extra buildings is well worth getting. Most games now finish with only one shuffle of the deck during the game. The scoring has been tweaked and all the extra buildings give so many more choices and combinations that I've raised my ranking. It's breathed new life into an already decent game. Not just a minor upgrade.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
San Juan and Race for the Galaxy are very similar games, mechanically. Each round, each player selects one role (producer, trader, etc.) and then all players perform the actions associated with that role; the player who chose the role receives an extra benefit. In Race for the Galaxy, the role selection is done simultaneously while in San Juan it is done in turn order. In both games, cards have multiple uses: they are played to a tableau to build plantations or settlements or developments; they are used to pay for the buildings being built; they are used to produce goods on plantations/settlements which are later traded in to get still more cards back into your hand. The object of both games is to build out 12 cards in your tableau and have the highest combined score resulting from those 12 cards. Both games involve hand management, choosing which cards to hold onto for building later and which cards to spend for building now. Essentially, they are the same game with different themes. San Juan, however, is much easier - it has a lower barrier to entry (the cards have explanatory text in English, whereas Race has a system of icons/hieroglyphics), but less variety, less depth/fewer strategies. San Juan is not a gateway game, it's got too many rules to be that, but it is a good gateway into Race. Race is the "step up" from San Juan. But, if you're not likely to play often, or with the same people, I would advise going for San Juan over Race - the barrier to entry for the latter can be enough that you may never get to play.

I actually find I connect more with San Juan, Race can be a bit overwhelming. I find, right or wrong, that I tend to enjoy a game a bit more if I have a good enough understanding to compete well and win frequently. I can do that in San Juan - I've never won a game of Race. The trouble with San Juan is that the strategies, once learned, become rote. It's still enjoyable to manage your hand and make the decisions on which cards to keep and which to spend, but at a certain level, these really aren't "decisions" any more - if you're playing a certain strategy then certain "decisions" become dictated/automatic. There's more going on in Race, more ways to win, so this sense of putting the game into "cruise control" doesn't happen as it does in San Juan. But, then, I've played San Juan over 100 times, using the AI, and I've only played Race a few times. Perhaps, once I've crossed the century mark with Race, I'll have the same feeling of "cruising" through the game....
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I know San Juan is Race for the Galaxy's poor cousin, but I prefer San Juan. Maybe it's because of the more direct confrontation (can't use a role if it was picked by somebody else) and/or the buildings are easier to relate to than stupid worlds and developments (not a sci-fi fan). I also like Puerto Rico, so the similar theme doesn't hurt. I think this game would be better if it includes shipping from Puerto Rico, like how Race for the Galaxy did (only thing I like about RftG), and the sweetening of unused roles.

Like this best with 3, as the strategy space is maximized without causing undue frustration. 2-player almost always degenerates into a race of quantity versus quality of building, and some cards (Market Stand, Trading Post etc) seem useless in the 2-player game. 4-player sucks simply because you're going to get stuck picking shitty roles.

RATING: 9.5
[COLOR=#663300][b][size=11]San Juan[/size][/b][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#663300][i]Note: My numeric ratings disregard BGG's associated verbal descriptions.[/i][/COLOR]

[COLOR=#006600][b]Comments: [/b][/COLOR]

Excellent at each number of players and different enough to warrant playing at each number, as well.  

After many plays, familiarity with the cards made the game a bit predictable for me.  Luckily, I found that the expansion cards (from Alea's [thing=40688]Treasure Chest[/thing]) breathed new life into the game without changing its character.

[COLOR=#006600][b]Why we own it: [/b][/COLOR] 

It's one of my favorites.

[COLOR=#006600][b]Details:[/b][/COLOR]

[COLOR=#006600]Version played: [/COLOR]2004 Rio Grande Games, English
[COLOR=#006600]Play History: [/COLOR]
 [COLOR=#006600] • 2 players: [/COLOR] Excellent.
 [COLOR=#006600] • 3 players: [/COLOR] Excellent.
 [COLOR=#006600] • 4 players: [/COLOR] Excellent.

[COLOR=#006600]Instructions: [/COLOR][COLOR=#CC0000]Must evaluate.[/COLOR]
[COLOR=#006600]Learning Curve: [/COLOR]I initially expected a tough time learning the various cards and interactions, but the learning curve was actually quite quick.  Managing cards, on the other hand...
[COLOR=#006600]Depth: [/COLOR]Strategy will depend on the cards initially drawn.
[COLOR=#006600]Luck: [/COLOR]Certain cards [i]can[/i] make a huge difference if acquired early in the game.
[COLOR=#006600]Downtime: [/COLOR]Low.
[COLOR=#006600]Fiddliness: [/COLOR]Fair.
[COLOR=#006600]Components: [/COLOR]Standard euro-quality, with great artwork
[COLOR=#006600]Player Interaction: [/COLOR]Low.
[COLOR=#006600]Conflict: [/COLOR]Indirect at worst.
[COLOR=#006600]Theme: [/COLOR]Not strongly atmospheric, but the theme does provide a framework whereby the play makes sense, and learning the game is made easier.

[COLOR=#006600]Travel related: [/COLOR]Suitable for play at destinations, not for play during travel itself.
 [COLOR=#006600]• Size: [/COLOR]Small.
 [COLOR=#006600]• Weight: [/COLOR]Light to medium.
 [COLOR=#006600]• Table Required: [/COLOR]Yes.
 [COLOR=#006600]• Footprint: [/COLOR]Large
 [COLOR=#006600]• Component Trackability: [/COLOR]Fair
 [COLOR=#006600]• Replaceability: [/COLOR]Available as of Jan 2010

RATING: 10
[30 plays] [2 player rating = 10] [3-4 player rating = 7] 

Puerto Rico's cute stepchild. More luck, a little less balanced (there are some relatively rare and extremely powerful cards that can make or break your game if one player gets combos early like the Chapel, Library, City Hall, Prefecture, and Guild Hall and others from the expansion like the Harbor), less strategic options, and less diverse mechanics. 

All that said and you might think I dislike San Juan, but you'd be wrong. It is an excellent card game that has some of the Puerto Rico feel with quick, tough choices. With 2 players and a little bit of time, hell yeah!, bring on San Juan. But with more than 2 players, I'd probably rather play Puerto Rico or perhaps another "meatier" game.

[All games post Alea Treasure Chest expansion are played with the expansion. I can't see purposely playing without it ever again, unless maybe teaching a beginner.]

Most recent play Dec '14.

RATING: 8
Elegant adaption of Puerto Rico to card game.  I like it a lot.  A lot of the luck of the draw is mitigated by the fact you have to use the cards you draw to pay for things, so drawing one good card is a good as drawing three.  However, getting the 'big building' you need to maximize your end game scoring is critical and if you are unlucky with your card draws, it will spell your doom.  Still enough meat and enough different strategies in a very compact package to satisfy.

RATING: 10
A nice "light" version of Puerto Rico.  Fun and much quicker to play than its older brother the board game (much quicker setup, too.)  A number of  strategies are available to pursue for victory.    My wife doesn't like this game at all and refuses to play it, but the rest of the family enjoys it enough and it has been getting good table time recently.  One major advantage for me is the fact that it can be played *very quickly* and you can get in three games in an hour, if everyone is on their toes.    Update:  The more I play this game (including playing on the computer using the jsanjuan game), the more I like it.  The mechanics, the interrelationships of the cards, the paths to victory, they all add up to a "10" game for me!

RATING: 10
Does a pretty good job of capturing a PR feel in a card game whose components can be carried around in my coat pocket. After about 50 games I've decided my ratings are as follows:

Two-player: 10. With only one opponent all possible strategies come into play, most of the buildings are useful, and the game is at it's most skillful.

Three-player: 8. Still a good game with three, but not as intense.

Four-player: 6. Four players is by far the worst. There's a chance that one or two of the players won't have a chance due to not seeing six pointers, and with four roles occurring each turn rather than three the manoeuvring is much less interesting.

Rated a 10 at BGG as over 85% of my plays are two-player.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
 As with its design predecessor, Puerto Rico, this game is not one you can understand or learn to play well quickly. It is less procedurally complex than PR and can be taught relatively easily. While it features some of the procedural mechanics of Puerto Rico, it is an elegant NEW game. After about a dozen plays, I am learning that it could well take over 100 plays before I can truthfully consider myself adept at its strategy and tactics. In other words, it has a high replay factor; not a game you play and put away on the shelf. Rather, a game you seek out time and again because of an interest in getting better at it. A classic, by definition? The luck factor is a little stronger here, as you sit and wait for the right cards to show up so that you can execute a given strategy, but as with most "luck" games, all players are dealing with the same issue. As with Puerto Rico, I'll be going back time and again to get better, because it is just plain fun to do so.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Does a surprisingly good job of capturing the feel of Puerto Rico, while offering a much shorter game.  Like PR, players select a role on their turn, such as Builder, Trader, etc.  The cards in your hand have buildings on them.  Thus, when you build, it is from your hand, and you use the other cards in your hand as currency.  Game over when someone has built their 12th building.  

The fun part of this (like PR) is figuring out what everyone else wants to do on their turn and taking advantage of this by either avoiding that action (because they will do it for you) or taking it for yourself (with the privilege).  One twist that is unlike PR:  the big buildings in this game come up randomly, so it is risky to embark on a building strategy (many production buildings) with the intention of eventually building the associated points-multiplier big building (Guild Hall), simply because you might never get it in your hand.  It's also difficult to hang onto the big buildings early in the game because you don't yet have a cards-generating economy in place and you need to spend your cards in hand (not to mention the hand size limit).  This is my favorite card game for 2-4p.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Brand new sealed

RATING: 3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
After playing Race for the Galaxy and Glory to Rome, learning San Juan is a cinch. It's definitely the least complex and most newbie-friendly of the three. San Juan and Race are a lot alike, like the original Dominion compared to its expansions. For that reason, I can see how Race might replace San Juan with experience. But I can also see how Race might be too much complexity for others; San Juan might be the better choice for them. I don't know which of the two I prefer, but I prefer Glory to Rome to both. Stretching the analogy a bit, San Juan is to GtR as Dominion is to Puzzle Strike: a well-implemented mechanic in a good, reliable game, but just not as dramatic, interactive, or replayable.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
While I enjoy playing San Juan quite a bit and will rarely turn down the opportunity (great quick fix for Puerto Rico!), I feel as though the game is mildly flawed in regards to the value of certain buildings and strategies as they pertain to the luck factor.  Furthermore, the two player game can fall apart quickly if certain tweaks aren't made to balance the possible card draws and obvious strategies that result.  With tweaks, I'd rate this one an 8, but as published it suffers a bit.  The fact it can be set up and put away in two minutes, however, more than makes up for any drawbacks.

Edit:  Revised to an 9.  I was too quick and too wrong in my initial criticisms.  Balanced just fine... it's understanding how, within the context of a game, to maintain the balance, that is the trick.  

Edit 02/22/09 After playing again for the first time in geez... nearly a year, maybe?  I'm wondering if San Juan may have jumped the shark for me.  I played it a TON for three years or so and loved it.  But it just felt stale this last play, and I wasn't inclined to give it another go.  For the record, I'm not a fan of RftG, so it wasn't a case of moving on to that game as many others have professed.  I think there are just other games out there I like more.  Still, not going to revise my rating down -- this game deserves the 9, as I played it a huge amount and it took me years to grow lukewarm.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An unbelievably great job of making a card game out of Puerto Rico.  Sequels and spinoffs are difficult in most things, whether it's a movie or a game.  Then you have the added pressure of basing it upon the #1 rated game.  Then you have the design restrictions of a card game compared to a board game.  Excellent.

RATING: 5
Perhaps this game had a place in the world before Race for the Galaxy existed and you wanted to play a quicker card game version of Puerto Rico.  But as of now Race for the Galaxy does exist and there shouldn't ever be a reason to play this game.

If you have the time and want to play Puerto Rico, play Puerto Rico.  Otherwise there is nothing this game does that Race for the Galaxy doesn't do WAY better...so play Race for the Galaxy.

RATING: 6.5
Build when your opponent have no money. Produce when your opponent's capacity is full. Trade when your opponent have no goods. Council if you have no good cards. Put up the Library before your 6th building. Go only for silver and coffee production building. Forget about Indigo plant. You have no chance of winning if you do not have a single 6 cost power card out of the 12 buildings.

RATING: 7
Sweet little card game that plays quick yet seems to offer different strategies and choices while you try to get the most points out of your little town. Played with 3 but seems to fit for 2 or 4 players just as well.
I've heard that "Puerto Rico" and "Race for the Galaxy" play similar yet more complex which makes me really curious about those. I like San Juan but it is lacking something extra shiny to make it great, those games might have that.

RATING: 7.5
Played 2 games Race for the Galaxy the other week - and LOVED it! Worlds of possibility! So when I saw San Juan cheap, I picked it up.

Obviously not quite the depth of R4tG, but still a great game, I think - easy to forget when you're playing that the mechanics (which quickly become commonplace) are fantastic! From role-selection to the different uses of the cards, to the different ways to win, this is a class act!; all games we've played so far have been really close, with 6 point cards (and the Chapel) deciding it - Another Wife hit, too!

Has the feeling that after many more plays, we'll probably be a bit beyond it - not convinced it has amazing replayability, but for now, a definite hit!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Unfortunately called 'Puerto Rico - The Cardgame' in the Dutch edition, this bears much less resemblance to its 'parent' game than you might think. It's all about hand management and choosing the right mix of cards to play. In that respect, it is somewhat similar to the Settlers card game. In both games, certain card combinations make for nice effects.
Of course, San Juan is somewhat eclipsed by Race for the Galaxy nowadays. The funny thing is that I always rated San Juan an 8 and gave Race for the Galaxy an immediate 10. But I hadn't played SJ for more than a year and wanted to try again, curious to see how it would stand up to the usurper R4tG. It turned out I still like SJ a lot. If anything, it has its relative simplicity, maybe even subtlety, which is lacking in R4tG. We played three games of SJ in a row, and I would have wanted to play another game. Conclusion: San Juan is a great game that can easily hold its own against Race for the Galaxy, and really deserves a higher rating than I gave initially.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
San Juan is a brilliant little game. It is extremely elegant, very scalable (I enjoy it just as much as 2, 3 or 4 player game) and can be played roughly in 20min.
Simple to learn, it still poses a challenge once mastered, remaining a competitive game. It's very ingenious and original in the way that, the very same card can represent and become, depending on the circumstances, a building, money or goods. San Juan fills a hard to fill sweet spot of balance, scalability and simple elegance.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
For a while after acquiring San Juan I thought I'd make a mistake. I like it a lot more now, perhaps even more than Race for the Galaxy -- still quite strategic, but faster, easier to teach, and less fiddly. I even think luck could be less of a factor: San Juan is more forgiving of changing strategies if early investments don't pay off due to poor card drawing.

The extra building cards in the expansion are a must. The rating without them is a 7 or possibly a 6. The Bank validates card-heavy strategies (and the Tower), the Harbour adds a new early-game VP engine, the Residence adds a new wrinkle to building costs, and the Park can (in some circumstances) even validate the Crane. I previously thought the Cathedral was overpowered but subsequent plays have changed my mind.

What I like least is that the common draw deck can make some actions annoyingly fiddly, notably the Councillor. God forbid two players have a Gold Mine, or the action that should be the fastest becomes interminable downtime.

Rating history: 7 -> 8
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Completely aside from how cleverly its design echoes the design of Puerto Rico -- build just so many buildings during the game and make it happen in such a way that the progression rewards you -- San Juan is simply a nice, unpunishing game where the decisions you make keep working out profitably. The only question is, will the other players make theirs work out better? Even when you lose you know you took an interesting shot at it, and that makes for a satisfying game.

RATING: 4
Great card game that can be great competition for 2 experienced players. My partner and I had a great time learning to play this game together, and developing strategies and counter-strategies together. It probably has more depth than other couple friendly games such as Schotten Totten and Lost Cities, but isn't as daunting as Race For the Galaxy.

Update: as for Lost Cities and Schotten Totten, my partner and I have played this one a lot, so much so that I feel we have reached the top of the learning curve and games are now dictated by luck of the draw. Would still be willing to play as an end of night filler with 3 or 4 players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A very good card-based game. Obviously very similar in mechanics to the superior 'Race for the Galaxy', which was largley styled on this game. The number of cards means that there's quite a diverse amount of options/strategies that can be employed during the game, which in turn provides a large amount of replayability. I personally prefer 'Race for the Galaxy' as it possesses a fair bit more depth to the gameplay (mainly through the greater number of cards added through the expansions). I think an expansion for this game would certainly add to its longevity and I believe that there is scope for this i.e. extra violet cards. It's still a good enough game on its own, however I just don't think it's going to get played quite as much as other card-based games with added expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
For me, Puerto Rico is a more immersive and rich game.  The main problem I have with San Juan is that it is too luck based, as you are really dependent upon your draw.  This is in stark contrast to Puerto Rico, which has very little luck.  If Puerto Rico never existed, maybe I'd be less bothered by the randomness, but as it stands, I can't help but think of it as a pale, less satisfying shadow of its parent.

Also, note that there are very good two player variants of Puerto Rico published online that play at least equal to, if not better than, San Juan.

RATING: 8
Play this with my wife. It took several plays before I managed to 'get' the game. The one concept I learnt from this game that I've carried into other games is this; Never lose focus on the Game Objective of accumulating Victory Points. If your next move might give you a cool ability, but doesn't significantly improve your Victory Points, it's probably not a good move.

13-Nov-07: I've gotten past the 'fixed' strategy of only building high VP cards and now just concentrate on winning with whatever strategy I can think up with using the cards in my hand. Makes it much more fun that way. My wife and I love this as a 2-player game.

RATING: 8
This game requires multiple plays before it gets really interesting. You have to know the cards and how they interact before the game starts coming into its own. Once you know the possibilities, this is really fun. You could argue that interaction is low, but you must be keenly aware of your opponent and how to maximize your gains and minimize theirs with your action choice. I would not play with more than 2 players, though. With more than 2 I'd rate this a 5 or 6.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
San Juan feels very familiar to me as a combination of Puerto Rico and Race for the Galaxy.  I liked how quickly it played and the two player game felt like a fun chess match.  Although in both games we kind of settled into our strategies early (one person built buildings, one person did production and trading) so the role selection was straight forward and fairly uninteresting.  But there is the economy management and engine building that is fun.   I'm curious if there are more strategies than I've seen so far.  In our two games there were really only two strategies, so I fear you'll always fall into one or the other and it's just a question of efficiency and lucky card draw at that point.  I'd probably play this over Race (partially because I got totally burned out on Race and it feels more like multiplayer solitaire), but this doesn't quite scratch the same itch as [thing=3076][/thing]. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
- The New Buildings & The Events
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
omparable to Race for the Galaxy and like it, very fun. There are enough differences to make me want to play this while Race exists, but not enough to make me like it more.

Firstly, I like that the role selection is turn based and can't be replayed, meaning even though I might prioritize a build strategy, you will still have to do a little bit of production to stay in the game. Production becomes easier and more paramount, even though it loses some of that 'race' tension that RftG has in spades.   

Secondly, while I used to prefer the engine building/combos in San Juan, I wouldn't say it is 'better' but more refined and less chance of not getting the combination you want/need. RftG has an uncanny way of players being able to scramble together something good even if it doesn't go as initially planned, which I find very fun, meanwhile San Juan does it with a tighter card pool. But both make for very good engine/tableau building.

And I like that San Juan is great with multiple players.

RATING: 7.5
San Juan is one of the better card games I've come across.  Unlike Glory to Rome, you have to build up your position throughout the game so that you can build the valuable 6 point building towards the end.  San Juan also plays differently with various #'s of players.  While fewer players favor a production oriented strategy, in 4 and 5 player, counseling is quite viable.  Deciding what to build and when can be a challenge--one minor gripe, this game has a bit of a learning curve, but its not fearsomely steep.

RATING: 8
Stripped down version of Puerto Rico with some of it's own unique qualities.

I love both, but, because it is lighter, faster, easier to set-up/take down, I find San Juan to be more fun.  

Requires very little space to carry or play so it's great for travel.

A version of Puerto Rico that is simple, but still has some meat, is portable, scales well from 2-4 and easy to set up.  
Great!

Update:  Still holding at an 8 and the Alea Treasure Chest expansion might bring it up. I have been exploring Glory to Rome lately, but I doubt it will take San Juan's place.  San Juan is just too clean and easy.

Update: Holds at an 8. Probably played this 30 times and the expansion has kept it somewhat fresh. Regarding my above comment on GtR: San Juan is a better 2-player game, so no worries about San Juan being replaced.




Suitability for Travel:

I have a 1 to 5 scale for four categories (1 is worst, 5 is best) in order of importance:

Portability (the less luggage space the better) - 4
Footprint (the less table space when playing the better) - 4
Scalability (the wider range of player counts the better) - 3
Learnability (the easier to teach non-gamers the better) - 3


Overall - 4

RATING: 6.75
Quick game with some nicely streamlined mechanics.  Very easy to pick up for Puerto Rico players, and not too hard for everyone else.  Using cards for goods, cash and points (under the chapel) is clever.  The order that you receive cards in keeps the game from getting too samey, but it feels like the learning curve is pretty quick as far as optimum strategies go.  We'll have to see how much longer this one holds its shine.  I held off on buying this while I was getting a lot of play out of a friend's deck, and then never looked back after [gameid=28143] came out.  Now I can't imagine ever wanting to play this instead of RftG.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I picked this game up used based on a recommendation and have never once regretted it. This is the favorite 2 player game for my wife and I. It's easy to pack, easy to set up, easy to put away. Plays go quick and there's no backstabbing element. The game has sufficient complexity so that each play feels different and there is enough strategy that a sharp player will have a clear advantage over one who is not able to adjust their strategy based on the cards they've been dealt.

The game has a radically different feel with 3 or more players. It feels far more random, far more difficult to control the outcome with purposeful plays. I definately prefer this as a two player game.

**Update: After beginning to play Race for the Galaxy, this game has taken a back seat. Dropping rating as RTFG is my clear favorite of the two.

RATING: 3
I used to like this game as a two player game.    I never really cared for it with 3-4.  The game can get quite stale.  Once familiar with the game, the game plays you and you really don't play the game.  Its just a series of forced moves.  Its fun until the replayability factor runs out.  The cards given to you play you, instead of the other way around.  It fails to create a single difficult decision for me in gameplay, and I place quite well.  I think the game comes down to whoever gets the better cards, unless someone makes an error.  All the clever plays are obvious after a few games.

Update:  The three - four player still has replayability... but I don't enjoy it all that much.  So many games I'd rather play with 3-4 players.


After playing, I either got the cards or I didn't.  There is nothing I can do to be clever to mitigate the luck, councillor be damned  Meh, I miss the great game everyone really likes.  I just don't see it. There is a low strategic ceiling that gets masked because of the random drawing of the cards.  Its short and fast, its just doesn't hit the strategy game button for me, nor the fun button for me.  

I had it ranked a 5 before Race for the Galaxy came out.  I would be pretty happy if I would never have to play San Juan again, which is a shame because I enjoyed exploring the system, but after the system was explored there was not anything left.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
It's fun to play and much easier than RFTG to learn (for my newb gaming friends). Library is a bit OP.

San Juan is no where near as deep, exciting or interesting as RFTG. Below are 2 (of many) reasons why.

1. The only reason to produce goods in San Juan is to get more cards. You can combo the production buildings with a 6-cost card, but other than that there isn't really much substance in it. In RFTG, goods mean a ton of different things, which opens up produce-consume strategies everywhere.

2. Indigo will always suck whereas novelty world goods can get really good with the proper card arrangement. If you've played both games you will understand what I mean by this. In San Juan, there's no way to arrange your cards into a killer indigo strategy when there are silver goods to get. This makes San Juan less deep and interesting than RFTG.

Even though I like RFTG more, San Juan is still fun for me to play and I'm happy I bought it. It's also pretty inexpensive. If you or your gaming friends look at RFTG and begin to cry, try San Juan and I bet you'll love it. Everything is explained on the cards and the rule book is very clear. In other words, you won't need to reference the rule book every 2 seconds for the first 10 games.

RATING: 7
[Rated 2005/05/06 based on 7 plays]

Two-player games seem to degenerate into "first person *not* to build something in a turn loses", but much more enjoyable with 3 or 4.

The fact that the cards you're trying to build are the same as the ones you're trying to build *with* force some agonising decisions as to what you can spend now in the hope you'll see it again, and what you really need to hang on to.

RATING: 9
I played this game on the computer in the form of JSanJuan many times before deciding to acquire a copy. Boy am I glad I did. It's (not surprisingly) more fun in person. The game is very quick for noobs to learn, teaching itself as you play. The game is very quick-moving, with lots of opportunities for simultaneous actions. The scores are often very close at the end. There is great decision making, and many combinations to be played. A very good game. If you like this, I recommend trying Race for the Galaxy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Very good game, but nowdays I like RftG more. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The more I think about/play this game, the more I realize it is a perfect game for me in so many situations. So many different groups can get into this one, as it plays fast enough, deep enough, and simply enough to keep everyone interested. Add to all that the superior 2 player game (which is to say, one of if not the best 2 player game made) and you've got a consistent winner that travels so much better than it's cousin Puerto Rico.

There seems to be a big desire in board gaming to create more of these medium-length, mechanically-simple yet strategically deep games. But I have yet to see one better than this....EDIT: until Race for the Galaxy. I won't go so far as to say this game is now obsolete, but for me, for now, it is. I will keep it highly rated because I can still appreciate it's qualities, but I don't need to play it much anymore because I would rather get in another RftG!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
down from 7.5.  my last play (or 3 if you count the previous 2 where i had "good" games and my wife didn't) were decidedly unimpressive.  too often one player gets behind early and then has a completely crap time of it.  with little to no way to catch up.  this may in fact be a rare occurrence, but it is too often for me to really like the game.  others may say that we should persevere, but why?  we've given it 4 games and it hasn't clicked for us.

would much rather a) play a different short cardgame, or b) play Puerto Rico (which i LOVE).

put another way:  too often player A had no good move, and every move s/he could do would massively benefit player B.  and player B always seemed to have a move that massively benefitted herself, but screwed over A.

too many unfun runaway games.

RATING: 6
I admire the system, but it doesn't work as well as I'd like. The small number of roles and the fairly rigid sequencing of some of them means play is more predictable than in Puerto Rico. There is also quite a bit of randomness - not too much if the rest of the game really excites me, but San Juan doesn't, so it does bother me. I think 6 is a fair rating for San Juan, but now that Race for the Galaxy is out I can't see myself playing this any longer - RftG does everything San Juan does, but ameliorates the luck to some extent, offers more paths to victory, and if anything is faster.

RATING: N/A
This might lead me to play Puerto Rico more. It borrows some mechanisms, and of course the theme. Otherwise, the good points relative to PR are that it plays much faster, and is simpler and easier to pick up. Bad points: much more luck than PR and less depth. Overall it is less intense, with less head to head competition for scarce opportunities (in PR the many ways of denying another player are almost a fetish; in SJ it's still a factor, but not key); it's more of a development race. I wouldn't say this is a truly great game, but it's deeper than it appears at first glance, and I enjoy it. I think a lot of PR players were disappointed by this being a lighter game, but on its own merits it's fine.

RATING: 4
Card game re-implementation of "Puerto Rico". Uses a unique mechanism where the cards not only serve as the buildings printed on them, but also as goods sold to obtain more cards or as currency to purchase buildings. Interesting mechanisms though it started to quickly fade for me after a few plays - the strategies seemed rather repetitive to me (go for either a "Violet" or "Production" building strategy depending on your initial cards). I felt like the luck of the draw would dictate whether you could pull off that strategy - the player that did would win. Traded along with "Colossal Arena" for Saint Petersburg in the 2008 Montreal Mathtrade.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
We have been playing this rather than puerto rico. People can sit back and relax during this game, resting on the backs of our chairs, sipping wine or beer, cracking jokes and ancedotal jibber jabber..a lazy man's puerto rico....in contrast, in puerto rico we are all hunched over the edge of the table plotting our next move....anxiety, anticipation, holding our bladders until no longer possible. Last game i got a chapel in the first round and just milked that thing for all it was worth....and i won by eight million points.

RATING: 7
First time I tried this game, I was still fairly new to hobby gaming, and the way things interconnect didn't make sense and I almost traded it away.

Revisited it more recently and I'm hooked on it now.  Really an elegant little game.  Great little engine-builder in a small package with a short play time.  You'll see all of the cards there are to see in your first play through, so I wish there was a little more variety, but with what's included there are several paths to victory and you'll likely never have the same result twice.  Every turn is full of tough decisions and risks, it's great!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Andreas Seyfarth (Puerto Rico); A card game based on Puerto Rico. The pack of 110 cards consists of production buildings (indigo, sugar, tobacco, coffee, and silver) and "violet" buildings that grant special powers or extra victory points. Cards from the hand can be either built or used as money to build something else. Cards from the deck are used to represent goods produced by the production buildings, in which case they are left face-down. A seven-card hand limit is enforced once per round.In each round or governorship, each player in turn selects from one of the available roles, triggering an event that usually affects all players, such as producing goods or building. The person who picks the role gets a privilege, such as producing more goods or building more cheaply. Though similar in concept to Puerto Rico, the game has many different mechanics. In particular, there are no colonists and no shipping of goods; goods production and trading are normally limited to one card per phase; and trades cannot be blocked. Victory points are gained exclusively by building, and the game ends as soon as one player has put up 12 buildings. Many fans of San Juan find it to be much better as a 2-player or 3-player game than as a 4-player game.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Pretty good, but much simpler than Puerto Rico or RftG.  A good gateway for either of those games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a great cardgame for two.  In fact, it is my favorite cardgame for two.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a card game with the "flavor" of Puerto Rico, and you get to pick roles like you do in the original game, but the similarities sort of end there.  It's simpler, plays more quickly, and takes less time to set up.  That's always a plus for me.  It's a better game for 3 and 4 than it is for 2, but the neat thing about the 2-player game is that you can manipulate your strategy, since you get to pick two roles every other turn, to your best advantage.  I think the game scales fairly well, given its complexity and different methods for scoring.

Sadly, now that I have Race for the Galaxy, I may never play San Juan again.

100+ plays: computer
4 plays: 2 players
3 plays: 3 players
12 plays: 4 players

-----

Base game
Treasure Chest Expansion

RATING: N/A
A card game based on Puerto Rico. The pack of 110 cards consists of production buildings (indigo, sugar, tobacco, coffee, and silver) and "violet" buildings that grant special powers or extra victory points. Cards from the hand can be either built or used as money to build something else. Cards from the deck are used to represent goods produced by the production buildings, in which case they are left face-down. A seven-card hand limit is enforced once per round.
\13\\13\
In each round or governorship, each player in turn selects from one of the available roles, triggering an event that usually affects all players, such as producing goods or building. The person who picks the role gets a privilege, such as producing more goods or building more cheaply.
\13\\13\
Though similar in concept to Puerto Rico, the game has many different mechanics. In particular, there are no colonists and no shipping of goods; goods production and trading are normally limited to one card per phase; and trades cannot be blocked.
\13\\13\
Victory points are gained exclusively by building, and the game ends as soon as one player has put up 12 buildings.

RATING: 7
An excellent card game adaption of Puerto Rico. Very innovative card mechanics, particularly in the multi-use cards that act as buildings, resources and money...all depending on how they are played. San Juan packs a lot of fun into a fairly quick little card game.

Update: San Juan has been somewhat retired from our game group after the release of Race for the Galaxy, which re-uses a lot of the mechanics but adds a bit more meat to them. We still keep San Juan around, as it's easier to teach than Race, but almost everyone who learns eventually graduates to the newer game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Wonderfully simple yet challenging.

RATING: 8

I probably like Race for the Galaxy a little bit more because I find player interaction to be more interesting in that game, but this is certainly enjoyable as well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A simpler Race for the Galaxy,  using the Puerto Rico role-selection mechanic.  Uses the innovative mechanic where cards are played as both the buildings being built,  and discarded to pay the cost as money.

San Juan suffers a bit by having very few avenues (maybe one and a half?) for victory, with some cards being much more valuable than others (*cough* Hall *cough*).  On the other hand, you can view this as being elegant and streamlined.   It is a card game,  so there's a bit of a learning curve figuring out what all the powers are.

Not a bad optimization game,  but much rather prefer RftG for diversity of choice and strategic complexity.  

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Not sure why this wasn't more popular with my wife and I. A few plays but kinda felt like Puerto Rico light, don't get it out often these days.

RATING: 8
What I Like-
Tableau building. Building combos/economy to fuel later purchases. Many ways to build your engine but all lead to only a few overall strategies. The tension of using cards as the building or the currency. Role selection timing to your own benefit.

What I Dislike-
Limited strategies. Sometimes luck of the draw never allows you to see a 6-building that you need to gain the points from your strategy.

RATING: 9
Spin off from the board game Puerto Rico. Although the card game inherits mechanics from the board game (choosing roles, producing, building...), the card game feels and plays much different. For me, it's a bit more accessible than the board game and has a higher 'fun' factor. More luck than the board game but it's not irritating. Plus once you know the game, you can play it under 30 minutes. In summary, a challenging and fun card game.

RATING: 8.5
Best card management game for me, easily played in under 5 minutes. The original Race for the Galaxy. I enjoy this one more for its simplicity and it isn't as overwhelming as RftG. You usually cycle the deck at least twice and a new player can see and understand all of the cards at a quick glance. I understand complaints of a lack of depth and minimal winning strategies, but making the same game more complex (i.e. RftG) doesn't always make the game better.

RATING: 6
I've only played this once, and have never played Puerto Rico.  Admittedly, I was a little lost at the beginning of the game, but was getting the hang of it by the middle, and I think I had it by the end.  I probably shouldn't have rated this without another game or two under my belt, but if I get a chance to play again I'll update my score accordingly.

I enjoyed it, once I started understanding what I was doing.  I think there's a fun game here, and I like the different roles you choose each time, and the various ways you can use the cards by playing with them or paying costs with them, making you pick and choose between whether you'd rather use a card as generic payment or for the specific thing it can do for you.

I look forward to playing this again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good fun, simpler that RftG. My fiancé enjoys playing it too.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.25
This is what I call "Puerto Rico Lite". It a very quick and easy game to play and is one that I have really enjoyed playing with the family. It has also gone over well as a lunch time game.

While it does give a lot of the feel of Puerto Rico, it loses a lot of the tension and strategic elements of its larger sibling. There's also a lot more going on in Puerto Rice as well but San Juan plays in a fraction of the time.

The game uses the same "variable phase order" of Puerto Rico where during each round, players takes turns choosing specific roles and undertaking those specific actions. Where it gets interesting is that all players are able to utilize that role simultaneously but the individual who chose it is able to perform an additional benefit. It's a simple mechanic that actually brings forward quite a bit of strategy when having to take in to account timing while also trying to keep pace with your opponents.

The game takes advantage of using the cards for multiple purposes as well. You can use them for buildings, money and goods, and they also represent end game points. Being able to build structures that give you additional benefits is also great.

All in all, this is a very enjoyable and quickly playing card game. I have currently played it to a point where I'm needing a bit of a break from it, but it's something that I'll definitely hold on to.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Get 2014 edition, which includes expansion

RATING: 7
A 2-4 player action selection game. Each player selects an action and everyone gets to do it, but the person who picked it get a bonus. Players build buildings by spending other cards, then produce and sell goods to get more card. Buildings are worth victory points at the end of the game.

RATING: 7
Horribly overrated game.  With 3 or less players, the library is completely broken and needs to be removed, unless you don't mind a game that is decided by who happens to draw this one particular card.  Once you take out the library, the game becomes more balanced, but less fun.  Isn't in the same league as Puerto Rico and is definitely not a substitute.  One nice thing about this game vs. PR though, the setup is much quicker and so makes for a better game if you have limited time to play.  Also, the box and components themselves are the nicest of any game I own.  The plastic insert that holds everything is a work of art.

RATING: 7
[b]EXCEPTIONAL AND INSPIRATIONAL[/b]

Millions of years in the future, when shiny robots sift through the remains of our gaming civilisation, they may well stumble upon San Juan, declaring it, rightly, to be one of the most valuable artefacts of this epoch.

The coin-card mechanism is genius. That's it. Said.

San Juan is all about building the most efficient economic engine - which is the sole reason I can't justifiably rate it higher, being the theme-whore that I am.

RATING: 6
The game flows nicely and is easy to learn, but provides some decent decision making every round (an indivudual card might be a resource, building, money etc... what is it best used for?)  I can't really find a strong con for this game, but it got somewhat repetitive to play... I don't think there are more than a couple strategies and whether the one you choose is successful or not comes from the draw of the cards.  A common attribute of card games I know... but I think I was looking for something more with this one.

RATING: 6
Basically a race to the finish.  What your opponents do usually have little to no effect on your choices, besides the fact that you do not want to pick roles that will greatly benefit them over yourself.  Always important to have buildings in the beginning that will restock your hand as fast as possible.  I do like San Juan quite a bit, but I think after several games under my belt, the flow rarely changes, nor do the decisions you make.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An impulse purchase to relieve finals week stress.  We are very happy with it though.

It took us quite awhile to notice some good strategies, but I would say that we are still learning what is most effective.  I think ultimately, you have to be flexible depending on the cards you are given.  There is also enough luck to really throw it off.  I think of all the sessions of this, only two haven't been two-player, so I will have to see how that changes things.

Update:  I finally figured out how the Crane is useful.  (About two years after we bought the game...)

RATING: 8
This is a fun, versatile card game that has of late been overshadowed by "Race for the Galaxy" for many, but I believe they can co-exist. The biggest issue I have with it now is the same I had with it when I first played: The theme isn't very exciting. Still, the game offers a beautiful balance of strategy and tactics. Certainly one of the most interesting card games I know, and now made even better by its expansion(s).

RATING: 7
Interesting, but not as deep as I had hoped.  There are some great resource management aspects to this game as the cards have multiple functions.  This'll come out as a nice filler game between the heavier games on game day.  It fills the same role as Fairy Tale for our group.

Rating has dropped somewhat since Race for the Galaxy scratches the same itch with more depth.  This one doesn't coexist well with RftG in my collection.

RATING: N/A
Escoge entre los 5 roles y todos realizan la acción correspondiente. Cada carta puede tener 3 usos: dinero cuando esté en la mano, edificios jugadas en el área de juego o recursos sobre los edificios de producción. Los  edificios dan habilidades especiales y PV. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
2-player version is definitely not as enjoyable.

Despite Puerto Rico's clever role-selection mechanic remaining intact (as long as you play with 3+), the random elements of a card game, coupled with the added randomness of the Trade action and the fact that some buildings are strictly superior to others bring this one down quite a bit in my book.

On the plus side, it's pretty easy to teach, and plays rather quickly. Given the chance, I would still much rather play RftG over this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I prefer it over Puerto Rico, due to shorter set-up and playing time. There are not the dramatic choices about trading/shipping, so that a game will never be spoilt in single turn. And the box has a perfect tray!

RATING: 6.5
